**Leopard Attacks and Kills Toddler in Queen Elizabeth National Park, Uganda**

A devastating incident has occurred in Queen Elizabeth National Park, Uganda, where a leopard attacked and killed a 2-year-old toddler. The child, identified as Elisha Nabugyere, was left in the care of a nanny at the staff quarters of Mweya Safari Lodge when the leopard snatched him on Friday night. The nanny heard the child scream for help, but it was too late, and the leopard had vanished with the toddler into the bush.

According to reports, the child's mother, a game ranger at the park, was working at the time of the incident. The father, SSP Francis Manana Nabugyere, an officer at the police senior Command and staff college Bwebajja, expressed his shock and grief over the loss of his son. He also challenged the Uganda Wildlife Authority (UWA) to do more in ensuring the security of their staff and children.

The UWA has launched a hunt to capture the leopard, which is considered a threat to human life after consuming human flesh. The authority's communications manager, Bashir Hangi, stated that efforts are underway to track down the leopard and evaluate options such as relocating it to a different area.

This incident is the fourth unfortunate event to occur in the park in recent weeks. A pride of 11 lions died on April 11, a French tourist died on April 14, and another lion died at the end of April. The killing of the toddler has sent shockwaves throughout Uganda, where leopard attacks on humans are rare.

The UWA has provided a coffin for the burial of the child's remains, and the father is seeking compensation from the authority. He also wants to see heightened security measures put in place to protect staff and children.

The incident has raised concerns about the safety of tourists and staff in the park, and the UWA is working to address these concerns. The capture and relocation of the leopard are seen as a priority to prevent any further incidents.

**Key Facts:**

* A 2-year-old toddler was killed by a leopard in Queen Elizabeth National Park, Uganda.
* The child was left in the care of a nanny at the staff quarters of Mweya Safari Lodge.
* The nanny heard the child scream for help, but it was too late, and the leopard had vanished with the toddler.
* The UWA has launched a hunt to capture the leopard, which is considered a threat to human life.
* The authority is evaluating options
details.ground_truth: A horrifying story out of Uganda, where a toddler was grabbed and eaten by a leopard Friday at the Mweya Safari Lodge in Queen Elizabeth National Park. The 2-year-old boy's mother is a game ranger at the park and was working, and the boy was with his nanny in the kitchen of the family's home in the park's staff quarters, near a doorway. "He was seated with the maid when the leopard grabbed and ran with him," the boy's father tells the Kampala Post. But a spokesperson for the Uganda Wildlife Authority (UWA) says the boy followed the nanny outdoors: "The maid was not aware the child followed her. She heard the kid scream for help, she intervened but it was too late the leopard had vanished with it in the bush." The staff quarters are reportedly in a protected area that is popular with tourists, USA Today reports, but the family's home is said to be unfenced. A search team ultimately found some of the boy's bones, including his skull, and they were buried over the weekend. The boy's father says he expects compensation from the UWA and that the organization should do more to protect staff and their families. "UWA gave us the coffin," he says. "I have not talked to them about the incident but I would expect something reasonable to compensate me, although my son's life is gone." Leopard attacks on humans are rare in Uganda. The UWA spokesperson says efforts are being made to locate the leopard and possibly relocate it. "The hunt is on with the intention of capturing the leopard and removing it from the wild because once it has eaten human flesh, the temptations are high to eat another human being, it becomes dangerous," he says, per the Telegraph.

**Archaeologists Uncover 6th Century Relic of John the Apostle in Bulgaria**

In a groundbreaking discovery, archaeologists at a medieval fortress site in Burgas, Bulgaria, have unearthed a lead vessel containing ashes from the alleged grave of John the Apostle, one of Jesus' twelve apostles. The relic, a tiny lead tube measuring less than an inch long, is dated to the 6th century C.E. and is believed to have been brought back from the grave of John the Apostle in Ephesus, Turkey, by a pilgrim.

The discovery was made during excavations of the ancient and medieval port of Burgos (also known as Poros) on Cape Foros in the Bulgarian city of Burgas. The site, which was first excavated in 2008, has yielded a wealth of artifacts and buildings dating back to the 4th-6th century AD. The lead tube reliquary is considered one of the most important discoveries in the history of the Burgas Regional Museum of History.

According to Milen Nikolov, director of the museum, early Christians believed that the relic had healing properties, and pilgrims would collect a holy curing powder, known as manna, from the site of John the Apostle's grave. The manna was believed to have the power to cure all kinds of diseases.

The discovery of the lead tube reliquary is significant not only because of its age and significance but also because it is one of only 43 known lead tubes from the 6th century AD. The majority of these tubes have been found in Italy, with 20 discovered in the St. John the Baptist Basilica in Monza and 16 in the Bobbio Abbey in Italy.

The relic is also notable because it is decorated with crosses and has images of a cross with equal arms inside a medallion on one side and two overlapping crosses with equal arms on the other. The neck of the tube is also decorated with crosses.

The discovery of the lead tube reliquary is the latest in a series of significant finds at the Burgos site, which includes a 10th century Bulgarian royal seal and a 2nd century AD inscription carved into stone stating that "burgi" (fortifications) were built on the border of the Roman colony of Deultum.

The site of the Burgos fortress and the Cape of Foros is also famous for being the site of a major battle during the Second Bulgarian Empire in 1304 AD, in which the forces of Bulgarian Tsar Theodore
details.ground_truth: Archaeologists in Bulgaria think they've found ashes belonging to one of the 12 apostles. The team found a small lead container with ashes while excavating a basilica that dates back to the sixth century AD, reports Archaeology in Bulgaria. The markings on the inch-long vessel match those at the grave of St. John the Apostle in what is now Turkey, leading researchers to surmise that a long-ago Christian from Bulgaria traveled to the grave site and returned home with the sample of ashes. Such journeys were common around that time, reports Novinite. “Probably a pilgrim from the Foros Peninsula went on a pilgrimage to Ephesus, and came back here with this relic, which was then donated to the basilica on Foros,” says the director of the Burgas Regional Museum of History in Bulgaria. (The ancient basilica is located in what is now the Black Sea city of Burgas.) Archeologists also found a Bulgarian royal seal from the 10th century at the dig site, which includes a fortress, notes the Week. (Another archaeological discovery: an ancient underground city in Turkey.)

**Netflix Introduces Unlimited Maternity and Paternity Leave Policy**

In a move to attract and retain top talent, Netflix has announced an unlimited maternity and paternity leave policy for its employees. The new policy allows new parents to take off as much time as they want during the first year after a child's birth or adoption, with the option to return to work on a full- or part-time basis.

According to Netflix's Chief Talent Officer, Tawni Cranz, the company wants to foster a "freedom and responsibility" culture that gives employees the flexibility and confidence to balance their work and family life. The policy is designed to eliminate the stress and financial burden associated with taking time off, allowing employees to focus on their families without worrying about work.

Under the new policy, Netflix employees will continue to receive their normal pay while on leave, eliminating the need to switch to state or disability pay. The company believes that this policy will help employees return to work more focused and dedicated, leading to better performance and productivity.

This move is seen as a significant perk in the tech industry, where companies are increasingly competing for top talent. Netflix's policy is similar to those offered by other tech giants, such as Facebook and Google, which have also doubled their maternity and paternity leave policies in recent years.

While the policy has been praised for its flexibility and generosity, some experts have noted that unlimited time off policies can have their pitfalls. Extended absences can strain workplace relations and require employees to work with their managers and teams ahead of time to ensure that their absence won't jeopardize a project or deadline.

Overall, Netflix's new policy is seen as a bold move to attract and retain top talent in the tech industry, and a testament to the company's commitment to work-life balance and employee well-being.
details.ground_truth: Expecting parents wondering which company offers the best maternity and paternity leave in the US need look no further. Netflix announced yesterday that it is upping the ante, offering new parents unlimited, fully-paid maternity and paternity leave for the first year after having or adopting a child. The streaming video company based in Los Gatos, Calif., also offers unlimited paid vacation, and it's all toward fostering "a 'freedom and responsibility' culture that gives our employees context about our business and the freedom to make their own decisions along with the accompanying responsibility," writes Tawni Cranz, chief talent officer. The new policy "deserves high marks for extending leave to fathers," reports Fortune, "as well as understanding that the entire first year after childbirth can be challenging." It's a "landmark perk," reports TechCrunch, noting that Yahoo doubled its maternity and paternity leave in 2013 (to 16 paid weeks for moms and eight paid weeks for dads) to compete with packages offered by Facebook and Google because "the talent is growing up." A decade ago big company perks included free lunch and ping pong tables, but now the major moves are about helping employees balance work and home life because "experience shows people perform better at work when they’re not worrying about home," Cranz adds. Of course, employees will have to plan their leave with managers and coworkers in advance to make sure their absence isn't disruptive—behaving, you know, like adults. (See who beat Netflix to the punch.)

**Kansas City Couple Robbed and Shot While Buying Teen's First Vehicle**

A Kansas City couple, along with their 16-year-old son, was robbed and shot while trying to buy their son's first vehicle on Craigslist. The incident occurred on Wednesday night at an apartment complex in southeast Kansas City. The couple, identified as a 53-year-old man and a 55-year-old woman, were shot after they tried to purchase a 2007 Hyundai Sonata from a suspect who called himself "AJ." The suspect, along with two other men, approached the couple and demanded money. When the woman was pointed at with a gun, the husband stepped in front of her and was shot four times. The woman's right upper arm was shattered by a single bullet.

**Details of the Incident**

The family had gone to the apartment complex to look at the vehicle, which was advertised for sale on Craigslist. The father and son test drove the vehicle with the suspect, who then walked away to call his wife. Two men then approached the couple, armed with black handguns, and demanded money. The suspects opened fire when the husband stepped in front of his wife, and the woman's purse, containing $3,000, was grabbed by one of the suspects. The suspects fled in the Hyundai, which was later found abandoned.

Detectives are questioning four people about the shooting, and a reward of up to $7,000 is being offered for information leading to an arrest. Liberty-based Ferrellgas has contributed $5,000 to the reward, and the company's employee, who was injured in the shooting, is a kind and considerate man and a great father. Police advise people to use caution when meeting someone for an online sale and to trust their instincts. They recommend going to a crowded area, a business, or a police station and not bringing cash.

A couple who live in the Stone Haven Apartments in southeast Kansas City came to the aid of the injured couple. They pressed down on the couple's wounds as they waited for police to arrive. The woman, who is a lifeguard, used her rubber gloves to help stop the bleeding.

**Warning**

This incident serves as a warning to people to be cautious when meeting strangers online. Police advise people to use common sense and to trust their instincts when meeting someone for an online sale. They recommend going to a crowded area, a business, or a police station and not bringing cash.

As the potential buyer was examining the wares, two other men reportedly arrived sporting a gun; the three men then lifted the Xbox and other items and ran into nearby woods, police say.

A recent report by the Senate Commerce Committee has shed light on the multibillion-dollar data industry, revealing that major data companies are selling deeply personal information about consumers, including sensitive health conditions, financial information, and even lists of rape victims and people with HIV and AIDS. details.ground_truth: Secretive data companies are tracking almost every American's every move online—and compiling and selling disturbingly targeted lists based on that spying, a new Senate Commerce Committee report concludes. That includes lists of rape victims, people suffering from ailments including HIV, AIDS, and dementia, and people with substance abuse problems, a privacy group said in a hearing yesterday, as per CNN. Mailing addresses for police officers and domestic violence shelters—the latter of which are usually protected by law—are also for sale, as are lists based on demographics and economics, including "Ethnic Second-City Strugglers," and "Rural and Barely Making It." The World Privacy Forum urged Congress to act to "remove unsafe, unfair, and overall just deplorable lists from circulation." The Direct Marketing Association released a statement saying that while the lists are occasionally "used to disparage certain groups," they represented a "tiny minority" of marketing products. Overall the committee looked at nine companies, some of which refused to explain how they got their data or who they sold it to, Gawker reports. One company admitted it had sold social security numbers and banking information to an alleged identity theft ring.

**Astronomers Discover Evidence of a Ninth Planet in Our Solar System**

A team of researchers from the California Institute of Technology (Caltech) has found new evidence of a giant icy planet lurking in the outer reaches of our solar system. Dubbed "Planet Nine," this mysterious world is estimated to be five to 10 times the mass of Earth and orbits the sun at an average distance of 20 times that of Neptune. The discovery was made by astronomers Mike Brown and Konstantin Batygin, who used mathematical equations and computer models to infer the existence of the planet based on the motion of small, icy objects in the outer solar system.

**A New Era of Exploration**

The discovery of Planet Nine has sparked excitement among astronomers and scientists, who believe that it could be a game-changer in our understanding of the solar system. Brown, who is known as the "Pluto killer" for his role in demoting Pluto from its status as a planet, said that the discovery of Planet Nine is a "jaw-dropping moment" that could lead to a new era of exploration and discovery.

**The Search for Planet Nine**

While the discovery of Planet Nine is a significant breakthrough, it is still a theoretical concept, and astronomers have yet to directly observe the planet. Brown and Batygin are hopeful that their paper will infuse the search with new energy and that the planet will be spotted within the next few years. The researchers are using powerful telescopes to search for the planet, but it will be a challenging task due to its extreme distance from the sun.

**A New Definition of a Planet**

The discovery of Planet Nine raises questions about the definition of a planet and whether Pluto should be reinstated as a planet. Brown argues that Pluto is not a planet and that the International Astronomical Union (IAU) made the right decision in demoting it. He believes that the controversy over Pluto's status will eventually die down as people become more comfortable with the idea of a new type of object in the outer solar system.

**A New Era of Exploration and Discovery**

The discovery of Planet Nine is a significant milestone in the history of astronomy and marks a new era of exploration and discovery. As scientists continue to study the planet and the outer reaches of our solar system, we may uncover new and exciting secrets about the universe and our place within it.
details.ground_truth: Pluto is gonna be PO'd. While the dwarf planet tries to fight its way back into the good graces of Those Who Deem What Counts as a Planet, another icy orb even further out may snatch that designation first. Astronomers at the California Institute of Technology say a giant celestial body "lurking at the end of our solar system," as the Washington Post puts it, may actually be a planet, and they're even already calling it "Planet Nine." In their research published in the Astronomical Journal, the sky-watching scientists—one of whom is known as the "Pluto killer" for his role in getting Pluto demoted—think their find is five to 10 times as massive as Earth, and per the AP, almost as big as Neptune and orbiting billions of miles past that planet's orbit. Michael "Pluto Killer" Brown and Konstantin Batygin haven't seen the supposed planet directly, but say they can infer the "massive perturber" exists by how the orbits of smaller bodies nearby are affected by its gravitational pull, the Post notes. What's interesting is that Brown and Batygin originally set out to disprove the existence of Planet Nine. "We thought their idea was crazy," Brown says of the scientists who originally floated the idea of a large, hidden planet. But as they did their own research, they soon came to their own conclusion in what Brown calls a "jaw-dropping moment" that Planet Nine could be the real deal. Now they're simply hoping more astronomers join in to actually try to spot the alleged planet—and they're not concerned it will face Pluto's fate. "That's not even a question—it's definitely a planet," Brown says. Not everyone's convinced. "I have seen many, many such claims in my career," a planetary scientist at Colorado's Southwest Research Institute tells Nature. "And all of them have been wrong." (The Washington Post caught up with Brown for a Q&A on the latest Pluto-killing endeavor.)

**Libya's Ongoing Humanitarian Crisis: Thousands Missing, Mass Graves Discovered**

The situation in Libya continues to deteriorate as the country struggles to come to terms with the aftermath of the six-month-long conflict that led to the overthrow of longtime leader Moammar Gaddafi. Thousands of people remain missing, with estimates suggesting that nearly 60,000 Libyans have disappeared since the start of the conflict.

Rebel leaders have opened Gaddafi's prisons in Tripoli, freeing thousands of prisoners, but only about 10,000 have been accounted for, leaving families and friends to fear that thousands are in underground prisons or, perhaps, in mass graves. The Abu Salim facility, where Abdul Rauf was held for 48 days, was notorious for its brutality, with 1,200 inmates massacred in 1996.

Abdul Rauf, a 25-year-old rebel fighter, was reunited with his family members on Sunday after being held captive for 48 days. He shared a small cell with 70 people, all sleeping on the floor, and told them about the revolution in the streets against Gaddafi. The broken men finally had a glimmer of hope, and they hugged him and wept.

However, the situation is not limited to individual cases of missing persons. A harrowing story has emerged from Salahuddin, Libya, where Muneer Masoud Own, 33, said that forces loyal to Gaddafi slaughtered nearly 150 prisoners as rebels closed in on Tripoli last week. Charred bodies littered the ground around a warehouse, where detainees were kept, and volunteers estimated that they had seen about 150 bodies.

Muneer Own, who barely escaped an ordeal that started about a month ago, said that he and his brother were detained by pro-Gadhafi forces for reasons that were not explained. They were handcuffed, blindfolded, and put into a warehouse with about 60 others, where they were subjected to horror and deprivation. The detainees had no food or water for three days, and the warehouse filled with the stench of human waste.

In a desperate bid to escape, Own and the others found a reason to hope: Guards said they would soon release everyone. However, just before sunset on the promised day of release, guards opened the warehouse doors, but the door did not lead to freedom. They tossed a grenade into the warehouse and started shooting, killing dozens. Own ran for his life, but he lost track of his brother in the chaos and has not
details.ground_truth: Troops loyal to Moammar Gadhafi massacred some 150 detainees last week, according to volunteers who cleared charred bodies from the warehouse that had apparently served as the detainees’ prison. An escaped prisoner told his story to CNN: He and his brother were handcuffed and blindfolded for no apparent reason while out walking earlier this month. They were thrown into the warehouse with 60 others ages 17 to 70. The number inside quickly reached 175 as loyalists continued to imprison people. The detainees were given no food or water for days, said Muneer Own. Finally, the troops said they would set them free—but instead hurled a grenade at them and opened fire. About 25 people were able to escape, Own said; his brother apparently was not one of them. The mass of bodies was discovered when rebels eventually took over the area. Many remain unidentified, part of a growing number of prisoners whose whereabouts remain unknown, notes the Washington Post. Thousands—some of whom have been jailed for decades—could be in underground prisons or mass graves, rebels fear. Click through for one family’s story.

**Yo-Yo Dieting Linked to Increased Risk of Heart Attacks, Strokes, and Death in People with Coronary Artery Disease**

Recent studies have highlighted the dangers of yo-yo dieting, or weight cycling, for individuals with coronary artery disease. A new study published in The New England Journal of Medicine found that people with coronary artery disease who experience large fluctuations in weight are at a higher risk of heart attack, stroke, and death.

The study, which followed 9,509 men and women with stable coronary artery disease over a period of five years, found that those with the highest weight variability had a 78 percent higher risk of new onset diabetes, a 117 percent higher risk of heart attack, a 136 percent higher risk of stroke, and a 124 percent higher risk of death compared to those with the lowest weight variability.

Coronary artery disease, also known as coronary heart disease, occurs when the major blood vessels that supply the heart with blood, oxygen, and nutrients become damaged or diseased. Cholesterol-containing deposits and inflammation are usually to blame for coronary artery disease, which can lead to chest pain, shortness of breath, and other symptoms.

The study's lead author, Dr. Sripal Bangalore, emphasized the importance of maintaining a healthy weight to prevent and treat coronary artery disease. "It's not just about losing weight, it's about keeping it off," he said. "We need to be concerned about weight fluctuation in this group that is already at high risk due to coronary disease."

The study's findings are consistent with previous research that has associated yo-yo dieting with increased risk of poor heart health. Researchers have found that people with coronary heart disease who experience large fluctuations in weight are at a higher risk of heart attack, stroke, and death.

The study's limitations include its observational design, which cannot prove cause-and-effect between yo-yo dieting and increased risk of heart attack, stroke, and death. However, the researchers believe that their results warrant further investigation and highlight the need to examine how to help Americans keep weight off, rather than having it go up and down.

In conclusion, the studies suggest that yo-yo dieting is a serious health concern for individuals with coronary artery disease, and that maintaining a healthy weight is crucial to preventing and treating the disease.
details.ground_truth: Losing weight is one thing, keeping it off quite another. And now researchers are finding that among those with coronary heart disease (CHD)—which the Mayo Clinic reports develops from damaged or diseased blood vessels typically caused by blockage and inflammation—yo-yo dieting may dramatically increase the risk of stroke, heart attack, and death. Reporting in the New England Journal of Medicine, researchers say they followed nearly 10,000 men and women with CHD between the ages of 35 and 75 for about five years, monitoring changes in body weight and other health outcomes. The takeaway? "It's important to lose weight, but this data says you have to keep it off," lead researcher Dr. Sripal Bangalore at the New York University School of Medicine tells the New York Times. The highest weight fluctuation was on average 8.6 pounds over five years, while the smallest body weight changes averaged closer to two pounds, reports Medical News Today. Those who were already overweight or obese at the beginning of the study and who experienced the highest level of weight fluctuation experienced 124% more deaths, 136% more strokes, and 117% more heart attacks, meaning these CHD patients were more than twice as likely to suffer these negative outcomes in just a few years than people with CHD whose weight only fluctuated two pounds. This doesn't pinpoint a cause, as pre-existing heart problems could be the culprit, but researchers hope to study this correlation further. (Yo-yo dieting is bad for women's hearts in general.)

**Funeral Home Theft: Suspect Sought in Odessa**

A disturbing incident has shaken the community in Odessa, Texas, as a thief stole a wedding ring from a deceased woman's body at the Sunset Memorial Gardens & Funeral Home. The theft occurred on April 8th, just a day after Lois Hicks, an 88-year-old woman, passed away.

According to the family, the thief, described as a heavy-set white female wearing a brown long sleeve sweater, black sweat pants, and black sandals, entered the funeral home around 5:27 p.m. on Friday, asking where the restroom was. However, she instead went into the room where the casket was and yanked the ring off Hicks' left hand, tearing off part of the skin from the woman's finger.

The family had left the funeral home shortly before the theft, and it was not until one of the funeral directors called them to touch up Hicks' makeup that they discovered the ring was missing. A video surveillance recording captured the incident, which has been released by the Odessa Police Department.

The suspect is believed to have fled the scene in a red or maroon 4-door Saturn, and the family is offering a reward for information leading to her capture. The Odessa Police Department is urging anyone with information to come forward and contact them at 335-5784 or Odessa Crime Stoppers at 333-8477.

This brazen theft has left the family and the community in shock, with many expressing outrage and sadness at the thought of someone stealing from a deceased person. The funeral home's general manager, Bill Vallie, described the incident as "horrible" and said that it was the first time such a crime had occurred at the funeral home since it opened in 1999.

The investigation is ongoing, and the Odessa Police Department is working to identify the suspect and bring her to justice. Anyone with information is encouraged to come forward and help bring closure to the Hicks family.
details.ground_truth: A Texas woman was caught on surveillance video stealing a wedding ring off the finger of a dead woman Friday, the Odessa American reports. The body of Lois Hicks, 88, was in an open casket at Odessa's Sunset Funeral Home. The woman's family had just left the funeral home after a visitation service when a stranger parked outside, came in, and asked to use the restroom. Instead, the funeral home's manager says, she walked into the room with Hicks' coffin, grabbed the ring off her finger, and left. Hicks' daughter says some of her mother's skin was actually torn off during the theft. "I can't believe someone would be that low," she says. The surveillance video captured the alleged thief's license plate, and the family is pressing charges. The incident is being investigated as a felony, KOSA reports. The suspect is described as a heavy-set white woman who was wearing a brown long-sleeved sweater, black sweat pants, and black sandals at the time; she drove off in a red or maroon four-door Saturn.

**Tragic Death of 3-Year-Old Girl at Hawaii Dentist's Office**

A devastating incident occurred at a dentist's office in Kailua, Hawaii, where a 3-year-old girl named Finley Puleo Boyle suffered a heart attack and died after undergoing a dental procedure. According to the autopsy report, the likely cause of her death was the combination of sedatives and local anesthesia administered during the procedure.

Finley, who was previously healthy, was taken to Dr. Lilly Geyer's office at Island Dentistry for Children on December 3, 2013, for a dental procedure that included cavity fillings and root canals. During the procedure, she was given five different drugs, including Demerol, hydroxyzine, and chlorohydrate, as well as laughing gas and an injection of local anesthetic. Immediately after the lidocaine injection, Finley became unresponsive and went into cardiopulmonary arrest.

The autopsy report, conducted by Honolulu Chief Medical Examiner Dr. Christopher Happy, concluded that the sedatives and local anesthesia were the probable cause of Finley's death, classifying it as an accident. The report also noted that Finley's teeth were in good shape, with no signs of underlying heart problems or allergic reactions to the medications.

Finley's parents, Ashley and Evan Boyle, filed a negligence lawsuit against Dr. Geyer and her office, alleging that their daughter was not properly monitored while sedated. According to the lawsuit, Finley was not checked for oxygen levels for 26 minutes, and no one administered CPR when she went into cardiac arrest. The family's attorney, Rick Fried, stated that the allegations are "unproven" but declined to comment further due to the ongoing lawsuit.

Dr. Geyer's attorney, John Nishimoto, also declined to comment on the autopsy report, citing the lawsuit. However, it was reported that Dr. Geyer had a clean record with the Hawaii Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs, with no complaints filed against her or her practice.

In response to the incident, new state rules took effect in January 2014, tightening oversight of dental sedation in Hawaii. The incident serves as a tragic reminder of the importance of proper monitoring and safety protocols in medical procedures, particularly those involving sedation.

No criminal charges have been brought against Dr. Geyer in connection with Finley's death. The case highlights the need for vigilance and accountability in the medical profession to prevent such tragedies from occurring in the future.
details.ground_truth: Drugs are likely to blame for the death of Finley Boyle, the 3-year-old Hawaii girl who died a month after going into cardiac arrest during a root canal at a Kailua dentist's office on Dec. 3, according to the official autopsy report. The report says the combination of sedatives and anesthesia Finley received during the procedure probably caused her death, the AP reports. The report noted that Finley was healthy, and ruled out any signs of an underlying heart condition or an allergic reaction. The medical examiner's office ruled the toddler's death an accident, and no charges have been brought against Dr. Lilly Geyer, KHON reports; however, Finley's family has filed a lawsuit claiming Finley was not monitored for 26 minutes while she was under sedation. Geyer's office has since shut down, but Geyer's attorney calls the Boyle family's allegations "unproven." (Meanwhile, a young mother in Hawaii is in a coma following wisdom teeth surgery.)

**O.J. Simpson Granted Parole After Serving Nine Years for Armed Robbery and Kidnapping**

Former NFL star O.J. Simpson was granted parole by a Nevada parole board on July 20, 2017, after serving nine years of a nine-to-33-year sentence for an armed robbery and kidnapping conviction. Simpson, now 70, appeared before the board and apologized for his role in the 2007 crime, stating that he had "done my time" and was a model prisoner.

Simpson's parole hearing drew significant media attention, with many comparing it to his highly publicized murder trial in 1995, in which he was acquitted of killing his ex-wife Nicole Brown Simpson and her friend Ronald Goldman. The trial was a major cultural phenomenon, and its themes of racial bias, celebrity, and domestic violence remain relevant today.

During the hearing, Simpson claimed that he had been misled by associates and had no intent to commit a crime. However, one of his associates, Tom Riccio, disputed this account, stating that Simpson had orchestrated the robbery and had done more than just take his call.

Despite this controversy, the parole board voted unanimously to grant Simpson parole, with board member Tony Corda describing him as a "low risk to reoffend." Simpson is expected to be released as early as October and plans to move to his home in Florida.

**Internet Archive Efforts to Preserve Web Pages**

In other news, the Internet Archive is working to preserve web pages and fix broken links on the web. The organization is using crawls to archive pages as they are created and to preserve the versions of pages that are referenced. Overall, these news stories highlight the importance of preserving digital information and the role of technology in shaping our online experiences.

President Donald Trump held a 77-minute press conference on Thursday, February 16, 2017, in the East Room of the White House. The conference was marked by a mix of tense exchanges with reporters, humorous moments, and a series of claims and counter-claims about his administration's performance.

Trump began the conference by announcing his new nominee for Labor Secretary, Alexander Acosta, and touting his poll numbers. He then turned to the topic of the media, accusing CNN of having "anger and hatred" in its reporting and saying that he no longer watches the network. Trump also criticized the media for being "dishonest" and "out of control," and claimed that the public no longer believes the press.

The conference was marked by a series of contentious exchanges between Trump and reporters, including CNN's Jim Acosta, who pressed Trump on the topic of his campaign's ties to Russia. Trump denied any wrongdoing and accused the media of perpetuating "fake news" about his administration.

Trump also addressed the topic of his national security adviser, Michael Flynn, who had resigned earlier in the week. Trump said that he had fired Flynn because of what he had told Vice President Mike Pence, and denied that he had been aware of Flynn's conversations with Russian officials.

In addition to the controversy surrounding Flynn, Trump was also asked about the topic of Russia and his administration's ties to the country. Trump denied any wrongdoing and accused the media of perpetuating "fake news" about his administration's relationships with Russia.

Trump also made a series of claims about his administration's performance, including saying that he had "inherited a mess" from his predecessor, Barack Obama. Trump claimed that the economy was in poor shape and that the country was facing a number of challenges, including terrorism and immigration.

However, fact-checkers have disputed many of Trump's claims, including his assertion that he had "inherited a mess" from Obama. According to economic statistics, the economy was actually in better shape when Trump took office than it was when Obama took office.

Trump also claimed that his administration was "a fine-tuned machine," but his first month in office has been marked by a series of missteps and controversies, including the forced resignation of Flynn and the blocking of his executive order on immigration.

Despite the controversy surrounding his administration, Trump remains popular among his supporters, with 87% of them believing that the media is biased against him. However, his overall job approval rating is lower than that of past presidents at the same point in their administrations.

Fox News anchor Shepard Smith was among those who criticized the president, saying he "keeps repeating ridiculous throwaway lines that are not true at all and sort of avoiding this issue of Russia as if we're some kind of fools for asking the question," the Hill reports. Smith said Trump "owes it to the American people" to answer legitimate questions liked the ones about Russia that he dismissed as "fake news." But not all the reviews were so negative. A look at coverage: Yes, he was "combative," observes Mara Liasson at NPR, "but he was also funny and charming like he was with the press during all those years in New York as a fixture in the tabloids. ... I think that he will get a lot of credit for doing this. I think it will thrill his supporters." The Washington Post fact-checks what it describes as 15 "dubious claims" from the conference, including Trump's claim that he had the "biggest electoral college win since Reagan." Trump had a total of 304 electoral college votes, which ranks sixth in the eight elections since Reagan's 525-vote 1984 landslide. Only George W. Bush won with fewer than Trump. "I was given that information," Trump said when a reporter challenged him on the statement. The AP takes a close look at Trump's "I inherited a mess line" and decides the claim itself is messy. CNN contributor Jeffrey Lord, reacting to scathing reviews: “Lord, I think we saw two different press conferences," he said, per Raw Story. "From my perspective, I thought he was relaxed, he was funny, he was on point. He took the whole issue of the media, and he had a very candid conversation." Politico has an exhaustive list of the topics Trump covered during the 77-minute presser, ranging from nuclear holocaust to CNN, which he downgraded from "fake news" to "very fake news." BuzzFeed has video of one of the conference's most heavily commented upon moments: when Trump asked a black reporter if she could set up a meeting between him and the Congressional Black Caucus. Presidential historians tell the AP that no president, including Nixon during the Watergate scandal, has publicly turned on the press the way Trump did. "It was bizarre theater," says Rice University history professor Douglas Brinkley. "He turned a presidential press conference into a reality-TV show in which he can be the star and browbeat anyone who objects to him with the power of his office." GOP strategist and CNN contributor Alice Stewart also found a few things to praise in Trump's performance. "You can't say he's not responsive to the press," she tells the Las Vegas Review-Journal. "He answered all the questions from all over the press corps and put to rest the long-standing dialogue that he shuts down certain news outlets." Vox lists nine moments that it suggests back up Jake Tapper's description of the press conference as "wild" and "unhinged," including Trump's claim that "the leaks are real" but "the news is fake." Late-night hosts approached the press conference as gleefully as a kid unwrapping Christmas presents, and the Washington Post rounds up some of their best lines. "My guess is he did it because he's mad and he just wanted to blow off some steam," Jimmy Kimmel said. "The tone of the press conference was like if your dad found a pack of cigarettes under your mattress." David Graham at the Atlantic looks at the continual theme of complaint in the conference and wonders: Does Trump hate his new job?

**International Space Station Faces Cooling System Issue**

The International Space Station (ISS) has encountered a problem with one of its cooling systems, which may require a repair spacewalk. On Wednesday, a pump on one of the station's two external cooling loops, known as Loop-A, shut down after hitting a temperature limit. This forced NASA to reroute coolant into Loop-B, causing the crew to prioritize life support systems, electrical systems, and science experiments.

According to NASA, the situation does not represent a life-threatening emergency, and the crew was never in any danger. However, the problem has required a cutback in normal operations on the orbiting outpost. Engineers suspect a malfunctioning flow control valve for the station's ammonia coolant may have caused the issue.

Mission managers are trying to determine whether a software fix can get the valve working again or whether a spacewalk will be required. Sorting through all the issues might take a couple of days or as much as a couple of weeks. Routine maintenance for "Big 14" repair operations typically takes two weeks to plan, but this depends on the resources at hand and the urgency of the problem.

The ISS has been continuously occupied since 2000 by spacefliers who spend tours of duty lasting four to six months. The current plan calls for the space station to be maintained through 2020, although the United States and the 14 other countries supporting the $100 billion-plus station project are already considering extending its operating life.

The six-person crew on board the ISS consists of NASA astronauts Mike Hopkins and Rick Mastracchio, Russians Mikhail Tyurin, Sergey Ryazanskiy, and Oleg Kotov, and Koichi Wakata of Japan. The current mission, officially called Expedition 38, is scheduled to go until March 2014.

NASA has scaled back operations on the ISS, shutting down some non-critical systems, including those in the Harmony node, Japan's Kibo lab, and Europe's Columbus lab. The space station's life support system is still up and running. Officials may decide to perform an emergency spacewalk to fix the failed pump, but a decision has not been made yet, and it may take a couple of days to determine the best course of action.

**Hurricane Katrina: A Decade Later**

Ten years have passed since Hurricane Katrina made landfall in Louisiana, leaving a trail of devastation and destruction in its wake. The storm, which occurred on August 29, 2005, was one of the most powerful hurricanes in U.S. history, causing widespread flooding and damage to the city of New Orleans.

**The Warning**

In the days leading up to the storm, National Weather Service meteorologist Robert Ricks issued a dire warning to the public. His bulletin, which was titled "URGENT... SPECIAL MESSAGE," predicted that "MOST OF THE AREA WILL BE UNINHABITABLE FOR WEEKS. PERHAPS LONGER." The document also warned of "WATER SHORTAGES WILL MAKE HUMAN SUFFERING INCREDIBLE BY MODERN STANDARDS."

Ricks, who was the forecast coordinator for the Slidell, Louisiana, office at the time, has said that he was awestruck by the severity of the storm and the potential consequences. He has also stated that he would rather have been wrong in his prediction, but his local expertise and experience with previous storms led him to believe that the storm would be catastrophic.

**The Response**

Despite the warning, many people in the affected areas did not evacuate, and the response to the storm was slow and inadequate. Ricks has said that the response broke his heart, as he had done everything in his power to warn people of the monster storm that was coming.

**Legacy of the Storm**

The legacy of Hurricane Katrina is still felt today. The storm led to a major overhaul of the National Weather Service's forecasting procedures, with a focus on issuing more dire and effective warnings during true weather emergencies. Meteorologists like Gary Szatkowski, who issued a personal plea during Hurricane Sandy's landfall in 2012, have been praised for their efforts to increase the effectiveness of government bulletins.

Ricks' bulletin, which is now on display at the Smithsonian Museum of American History, is considered one of the most effective and dire weather forecasts ever issued by the National Weather Service. It serves as a reminder of the importance of accurate and timely warnings during severe weather events.

**Remembering the Storm**

As the city of New Orleans continues to rebuild and recover from the storm, it is essential to remember the lessons learned from Hurricane Katrina. In response to the incident, Twitter has promised to improve and expand its policies to better handle tragic situations like this one. The company has suspended several accounts related to the issue and is evaluating how to further improve its policies, including expanding its rules regarding self-harm and private information.

However, this incident is just a small part of a larger problem of online harassment on Twitter. Many users, including Imani Gandy, a senior legal analyst, face constant abuse on the platform due to their race, gender, and medical conditions. Gandy has reported the abuse to Twitter, but the company has failed to take adequate action.

Twitter's current system for reporting abuse is limited, and users often find it difficult to get help. The company's "Report Abuse" button is not effective in stopping persistent attackers, who can create new accounts to continue their harassment. Some users have even reported that Twitter has allowed accounts to remain active despite violating its community rules.

Experts, including Soraya Chemaly, a media critic and feminist activist, are calling on Twitter to take more robust action to protect its users from harassment. Chemaly suggests that Twitter could learn from third-party software like "Block Together," which allows users to automatically block new accounts that send them direct messages.

Twitter's commitment to free expression may be clouding its judgment on this issue, Chemaly argues. The company's failure to protect its users from harassment is not only affecting the individuals targeted but also the community as a whole.

**Target Impersonation Theft: Fairfax County Police Search for Suspect**

Fairfax County police are currently searching for a woman suspected of impersonating a Target employee and stealing over $40,000 worth of iPhones from a store located on Richmond Highway in Alexandria, Virginia. The incident occurred on March 15, when the unidentified woman, dressed as a Target employee, gained access to the stockroom and took the iPhones, placing them in a box before leaving the store.

According to police, the suspect was familiar with store procedures, employee hours, and the location of the iPhones in the stockroom, suggesting that she may have had prior knowledge of the store's layout. Surveillance footage shows the woman leaving the store and getting into a Volvo station wagon.

Detectives have released surveillance pictures of the suspect, and anyone with information about the case is encouraged to contact Fairfax County police at 703-691-2131. The suspect is not affiliated with the store, but appeared to have a good understanding of the store's operations.

The incident highlights the importance of security measures in retail stores, particularly in areas where valuable items are stored. It also serves as a reminder to employees and customers to be vigilant and report any suspicious activity.

The Fairfax County police are working to identify the suspect and bring her to justice. The public is urged to remain vigilant and report any information that may lead to the capture of the suspect.

- Date of incident: March 15
- Location: Target store on Richmond Highway in Alexandria, Virginia
- Value of stolen items: Over $40,000 worth of iPhones
- Suspect description: Unidentified woman dressed as a Target employee

- Contact information: Fairfax County police at 703-691-2131

Its source says the ICBM started moving Monday, is only being moved at night, and is headed toward the nation's west coast. Reuters notes there's some likelihood that another test could come on or around Saturday: Sept. 9 is the country's founding day holiday. CNBC notes North Korea conducted a nuke test on Sept. 9, 2016. Two more details that allegedly came from the South's National Intelligence Service briefing: word that additional tunnels have been dug out at the North's nuclear test site that would facilitate future detonations, and suspicions that the next ICBM test firing might be directed toward the North Pacific but aimed at a lower angle, which would in theory allow it to fly further than previous tests, which had more of an upward trajectory. Meanwhile, the White House tells Reuters it has given "in-principle approval" to a request by South Korean President Moon Jae-in to abolish a limit regarding warhead weights, a move that would strengthen the power with which it could attack the North, if necessary. Meanwhile, Vladimir Putin on Tuesday gave his take on the situation: North Korea "will eat grass but will not give up the (nuclear) program if they don't feel safe."

**Tragic Accident: 6-Year-Old Boy Killed in Deputy-Involved Shooting**

A devastating incident occurred in Schertz, Texas, on Thursday, resulting in the tragic death of 6-year-old Kameron Prescott. The boy was killed when deputies opened fire on a suspect, Amanda Lene Jones, 30, who was believed to be armed. Jones, a wanted felon and car-theft suspect, was shot and killed by four deputies, including John Aguillon, George Herrera, Jesse Arias, and Johnny Longoria, a reservist.

According to Bexar County Sheriff Javier Salazar, the incident began when a deputy responded to a report of a stolen vehicle and spotted Jones with what he thought was a weapon. Jones physically threatened the deputy and verbalized her intention to shoot him. She managed to escape and was later found at the Pecan Grove Mobile Home Park, where Kameron lived.

Jones forced her way into Kameron's home, threatened to shoot members of his family, and said she was taking their vehicle. Witnesses reported hearing her threaten to shoot the law enforcement officers. Deputies were waiting outside, and when Jones left the home, they believed she was holding an object in her hand that they thought was a weapon.

The deputies fired shots, and one of the bullets pierced the wall of the mobile home, striking Kameron in the abdomen. He was pronounced dead at a hospital. The deputies, as well as witnesses, reported that Jones had threatened to shoot them, and they believed she was armed.

An investigation is ongoing, and the local district attorney is reviewing the incident. The deputies involved have been placed on administrative leave. The school district has established a fund to assist Kameron's family with expenses.

Kameron was described by his teacher, Shanda Ince, as "the kindest-hearted little boy that I have ever had the pleasure of teaching." He was a first-grader at Wiederstein Elementary School and was known for his big heart, happy personality, and ability to make everyone laugh.

The community is mourning the loss of Kameron, and the incident has left many wondering how it could have been prevented. The Bexar County Sheriff's Office has released a statement saying that the incident was a "tragic accident" and that policies were followed. However, the investigation is ongoing, and the community is seeking answers.

**Key Facts:**

* Kameron Prescott, 6, was killed in a deputy-involved shooting on Thursday.
* Amanda Lene Jones, 30
details.ground_truth: Sheriff's deputies shot and killed a 6-year-old boy Thursday in Texas, WOAI reports. Bexar County Sheriff Javier Salazar says four deputies opened fire on 30-year-old Amanda Jones, a suspected car thief, after they "cornered" her outside a mobile home occupied by Kameron Prescott and his family in the town of Schertz. One of the bullets went through the mobile home and hit Kameron in the abdomen. According to CNN, Salazar says deputies performed first aid on the boy, but he was pronounced dead at the hospital. Jones was also killed. "The deputies are, of course, understandably shaken up," Salazar says. He says the shooting is under investigation, but in his opinion the boy's death is "a tragic accident." Salazar says one deputy is "adamant" he saw Jones with a gun and that she threatened to shoot him. He says Jones threatened both police and Kameron's family, who didn't know her, just before deputies opened fire. But investigators haven't been able to locate a gun despite the use of a helicopter and dive team. Salazar says they have found a pipe with Jones' blood on it near the scene of the shooting. One deputy at the scene was wearing a body camera, but he blocked it with his rifle during the shooting. Meanwhile, Kameron is being remembered by those who knew him. "Kameron was a ball of energy, happy, smart, and could strike up a conversation with anyone,” school counselor Maria Morales tells KSAT. “He also had a great sense of humor and caring heart."

**Vegan Mother's Custody Battle: A Year of Turmoil**

In a dramatic turn of events, a Seminole County, Florida, mother, Sarah Markham, has regained custody of her newborn son, Caleb, after a year-long battle with Child Protective Services (CPS). The case began in June when Markham, a vegan, refused to take her dehydrated newborn to the hospital, citing her dietary preferences.

According to reports, Markham's pediatrician had ordered her to take Caleb to the hospital due to his rapid weight loss, but she instead opted to try supplementing breast milk with vegan formula. This decision led to her arrest on charges of child neglect.

However, in a surprising twist, a Seminole County judge has ruled in Markham's favor, stating that there was no evidence of abuse or neglect. The judge also ordered Markham to provide a nutritionist's report within 10 days, which she has since done.

Markham's lawyer, Mark O'Mara, has expressed hope that the criminal case against his client will be dismissed. Caleb, who was removed from his mother's care and placed with his grandparents, has since gained weight and is thriving on a soy formula.

Markham's grandfather, Bo Markham, has spoken out in support of his daughter, stating that there was no case of abuse or neglect, but rather a doctor who was challenged by a mother who knew what was best for her child.

The case has sparked debate about the rights of parents to make decisions about their children's care, particularly when it comes to dietary choices. While some have criticized Markham's decision to refuse medical treatment for her child, others have praised her for standing up for her values and advocating for her child's well-being.

As the case continues to unfold, one thing is clear: the Markham family's story is a complex and multifaceted one, filled with twists and turns that have captivated the public's attention.
details.ground_truth: A judge in Florida has allowed a vegan mom who defied a doctor's orders to regain custody of her infant son, reports WFTV. The strange case began in June when police in Casselberry charged Sarah Markham with neglect and took away 2-week-old Caleb. The charges came after a pediatrician diagnosed Caleb as dehydrated and underweight, and told Markham to take him to the hospital immediately, recounts WKMG. Instead, Markham bought soy formula to supplement her breast milk. When she didn't show up at the hospital, police came to her house, and she told them she wanted a second doctor's opinion and stressed that she did not want her son getting formula from animal products. Today, a Seminole County judge granted her custody again with the provision that she provide a nutritionist's report in 10 days. "There's no case, there's no abuse, there's no neglect—there's simply a doctor who has been challenged by a mother, and he didn't like it," says Caleb's grandfather, Bo Markham. The child has been with his grandparents since he was taken out of his mother's care, and now weighs about 17 pounds. "He's still on a soy formula," says Bo Markham. The criminal neglect charges are still pending, though Sarah Markham's attorney—Mark O'Mara, who defended George Zimmerman—says he expects they will be dismissed now. (PETA wants an Indiana sheriff to feed an alleged cannibal a vegan diet.)

**Rising Colorectal Cancer Rates Among Younger Adults: A Growing Concern**

A recent analysis of data from the United States has revealed a disturbing trend: one in seven colon and rectal cancer patients is now under the age of 50, the age at which guidelines recommend screenings start. This shift in demographics has significant implications for the medical community, as younger patients are more likely to be diagnosed with advanced stage cancer, but also tend to live slightly longer without a cancer recurrence due to aggressive treatment.

According to a study published in the journal Cancer, researchers analyzed data from nearly 260,000 patients diagnosed with colon cancer between 1998 and 2011. The results showed that 37,847 patients, or approximately 15 percent, were under the age of 50. These younger patients were more likely to be diagnosed with advanced cancer and were more likely to undergo surgery and radiation therapy than older patients.

Despite the increased risk of advanced cancer, younger patients tended to live longer without a cancer recurrence. The five-year survival rates for patients under 50 were 95.1 percent for localized disease, 76 percent for regional disease, and 21.3 percent for distant disease, compared to 91.9 percent, 70.3 percent, and 14.1 percent, respectively, for older patients.

The reasons for the increase in colon cancer among younger adults are unclear, but experts suggest that environmental factors, such as smoking, obesity, and physical inactivity, may be contributing to the trend. Dr. Andrew Chan, an associate professor of medicine at Harvard Medical School, noted that "it's not simply a change in diagnoses, it's a very real increase."

The findings of this study raise important questions about the current guidelines for colon cancer screening. While some experts argue that the data do not support expanding screening to younger age groups, others suggest that the medical community needs to prepare for the increasing number of very young colorectal cancer survivors who will need long-term support to cope with the physical and psychological consequences of their disease and treatments.

In light of these findings, it is essential for doctors to be aware of the warning signs of colon cancer, such as anemia, bowel bleeding, or a blockage in the colon. People with a family history of colon cancer and those who are at higher risk should begin screening earlier than the age of 50. Ultimately, further research is needed to understand the causes of this trend and to determine the best course of action for preventing and treating colon cancer in younger adults.

**Key Statistics
details.ground_truth: A new study says one in seven US colon cancer patients is younger than 50—raising questions about why more young people seem to be getting the disease and what can be done about it, reports HealthDay via the Philadelphia Inquirer. "Colon cancer has traditionally been thought of as a disease of the elderly," says lead author Samantha Hendren. "This study is really a wake-up call to the medical community that a relatively large number of colon cancers are occurring in people under 50." Using government data on almost 260,000 colon-cancer patients from 1998 to 2011, the study also says younger patients more often have advanced cancer and undergo surgery (72% compared to 63% of patients over 50). The young are also more likely to use radiation therapy (53% to 48%) and have a slight advantage in surviving for five years (68% to 67%). Younger people are more likely to have advanced colon cancer partly because they get tested after noticing symptoms (like colon blockage, bleeding, and anemia), while people over 50 are advised to begin screenings, says Hendren. "Unfortunately, these symptoms are often ignored by the patient or doctor or ascribed to something like hemorrhoids," a scientist adds, per Reuters. Hendren's team conducted the study after noticing a rise in colon cancer among young people, Medical Daily reports, but that spike remains unexplained. Physical inactivity, obesity, smoking, and "an effect in our environment" are all possible causes, a Harvard professor says. More screenings for young people might help, but the yield would be low because under-50s are still less likely to get colon cancer. "This would be a big and costly change," says Hendren, who recommends "a lot of research" be done first. (A new killer is expected to top cancer by 2050.)

**Ancient Human Settlements in Australia Uncovered**

Archaeologists have made a groundbreaking discovery in southern Australia, uncovering a human settlement dating back 49,000 years. The site, known as Warratyi rock shelter, is located in the Flinders Ranges, about 550 kilometers north of Adelaide. The discovery was made by chance when a colleague needed to use the restroom, and the area was surveyed with an Aboriginal elder.

**Significance of the Discovery**

The site is crucial in understanding human settlement in Australia, and the age of the site is significant. The previous oldest-known site in the arid zone, located at Puritjarra in western Central Australia, is around 38,000 years old. This discovery pushes back the earliest-known dates on the development of key bone and stone axe technologies and the use of ochre in Australia.

**Evidence of Human Interaction with Megafauna**

The site also contains evidence of human interaction with megafauna, including the Diprotodon optatum, a marsupial measuring 2m in height and weighing more than 2,500kg. The presence of bones from juvenile animals in a cave on a cliff suggests they were hunted. This discovery is significant in the debate over the extinction of megafauna, as it suggests that humans may have played a role in their extinction.

**Dating of the Site**

The age of the site was determined through a combination of optical dating of quartz grains and radiocarbon dating of hearth charcoal and eggshell samples. The results indicate that humans occupied the site from 49,000 to 46,000 years ago.

**Implications of the Discovery**

The discovery has significant implications for our understanding of human settlement in Australia. It suggests that humans were able to migrate south quickly, and that they had developed complex technologies and social structures. The discovery also challenges the Eurocentric view that Indigenous Australians were not as innovative as similar populations elsewhere in the world.

**Future Research**

The site will continue to be excavated, and further research will be conducted to learn more about the lives of the people who lived there. The discovery of the Warratyi rock shelter is a significant milestone in the study of human settlement in Australia, and it will continue to be an important site for researchers in the years to come.

**Quotes from Researchers**

* "The old idea is that people might have come from the East, from the Levant, out of Africa, and these modern humans may have come with a package of innovative technologies.
details.ground_truth: "A man getting out of the car to go to the toilet led to the discovery of one of the most important sites in Australian pre-history," archaeologist Giles Hamm tells ABC News. Hamm was surveying a section of Australia's Flinders Ranges when his partner, aboriginal elder Clifford Coulthard, had to go to the bathroom. "Nature called and Cliff walked up this creek bed into this gorge and found this amazing spring surrounded by rock art," Hamm says. At the time, Hamm thought the newly discovered human settlement, a site called Warratyi, was only 5,000 years old. It turns out it's closer to 49,000 years old, and that has huge ramifications for our knowledge of ancient Australian civilization, Sky News reports. Hamm and his team published a study on Warratyi this week in Nature. The discovery of Warratyi in the arid interior of the continent means humans either arrived in Australia up to 10,000 years earlier than previously believed—or they expanded across the continent at a much quicker rate, Science Alert reports. Researchers at the site found 4,300 objects, including tools, and 200 bone fragments from multiple animals, including a 5,500-pound marsupial. The bones help explain how early Australians interacted with megafauna, including hunting them. The tools show Australians were using bone and stone axes earlier than believed and are evidence that early Australians developed some technologies on their own rather than adopting them from other peoples as previously believed. (Ninety rocks in Australia could rank up there with Stonehenge.)

**Gaza Conflict Update: Israel and Hamas Agree to 72-Hour Ceasefire**

The Gaza conflict has entered its 24th day, with both Israel and Hamas agreeing to a 72-hour ceasefire starting on Friday, August 1. The ceasefire was announced by US Secretary of State John Kerry and UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon, who urged all parties to act with restraint until the ceasefire begins.

**Death Toll Rises**

The death toll in the Gaza conflict has risen to over 1,360 Palestinians, with more than 6,500 wounded. Three Israeli civilians and 56 Israeli soldiers have been killed. The Palestinian Health Ministry has reported that 315 children and 166 women have been killed in the conflict.

**Humanitarian Crisis**

The Gaza Strip has been declared a "humanitarian disaster area" by Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas, who has urged the international community to provide relief to the battered enclave. The UN has reported that nearly one quarter of the population of Gaza has been displaced, with over 225,000 people seeking refuge in 86 UNRWA schools.

**International Response**

The international community has condemned the violence in Gaza, with the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights accusing both Israel and Hamas of committing war crimes. The US has expressed concern over the rising number of Palestinian civilian deaths and loss of Israeli lives, and has called for a humanitarian ceasefire.

**Israeli Military Operation**

The Israeli military has continued its operation in Gaza, with tank shells striking a UN school in the Jebaliya refugee camp, killing at least 17 people. An Israeli airstrike also hit a crowded shopping area in Gaza City, killing at least 16 people. The Israeli military has said that it is committed to destroying the Hamas tunnel network, with or without a ceasefire.

**Ceasefire Efforts**

Egyptian officials have met with an Israeli envoy to discuss a ceasefire, but Hamas has said it will only halt fire once it receives guarantees that a Gaza border blockade by Israel and Egypt will be lifted. The US has said that it is working to bring about an immediate ceasefire, and has expressed support for a two-state solution.

**Reserve Troops Called Up**

The Israeli military has called up an additional 16,000 reserve troops to pursue its campaign in Gaza, bringing the total number of reserve soldiers called up to 86,000. The military has said that the purpose of the latest call-up is to provide relief for troops currently on the Gaza firing line.

**International Support**

The international community has expressed support for Israel
details.ground_truth: Benjamin Netanyahu today vowed to destroy Hamas' tunnels at all costs, even as Israel called up an additional 16,000 reservists—bringing the total so far to 86,000 troops. "We are determined to complete this mission with or without a ceasefire," he said of the tunnels' destruction, as per Haaretz. "Therefore I will not agree to any offer that does not allow the military to complete this important mission for the security of the people of Israel." He also issued a get-in-line message to two ministers who have been critical of his actions against Hamas, saying "beware of what you're doing." Netanyahu's statement vis a vis the tunnels comes as ceasefire efforts are sputtering anyway, notes the AP, and on the heels of the worst day of casualties thus far in Gaza.

**Snap's Spectacles Now Available for Purchase Online**

Snap, the parent company of Snapchat, has made its camera-enabled sunglasses, Spectacles, available for purchase online in the United States. The glasses, which allow users to record circular videos and post them to their Snapchat accounts, were previously only available through vending machines that popped up in random locations around the country or through a store in Manhattan.

The glasses, which retail for $130, come in three colors: teal, coral, and black. They can be purchased on Spectacles.com, and shipping is expected to take two to four weeks. The company has also limited households to purchasing six pairs of Spectacles.

The decision to make Spectacles available for online purchase comes as Snap prepares for its initial public offering (IPO). In its SEC filing, the company admitted that Spectacles have not generated significant revenue, and production and operating costs are expected to exceed related revenue in the near future.

However, Snap believes that making Spectacles more widely available will help the company to increase its user base and encourage more people to create and watch Snaps. The company has also stated that it will continue to use vending machines as a distribution strategy, although they will be taking a short break.

The online availability of Spectacles has been met with excitement from fans, who were previously forced to wait in long lines or pay significant markups on resale websites like eBay. With the glasses now available for purchase online, users can easily get their hands on a pair and start recording circular videos to share with their friends on Snapchat.

**Key Details:**

* Spectacles are now available for purchase online at Spectacles.com
* The glasses retail for $130 and come in three colors: teal, coral, and black
* Shipping is expected to take two to four weeks
* Households are limited to purchasing six pairs of Spectacles
* Pop-up vending machines will continue to be used as a distribution strategy, although they will be taking a short break.
details.ground_truth: Snapchat found itself with a marketing sensation on its hands late last year when it began selling funky-looking sunglasses called Spectacles. The trick is they allow users to record quick videos and photos and send them directly to their Snapchat accounts, but the catch was they were available only through vending machines that would turn up in random locales or through a now-shuttered pop-up store in Manhattan, notes New York. Now, however, parent company Snap is selling them online at Spectacles.com for $129. Just how crazy did demand get? CNBC notes that the glasses were selling for up to $5,000 on secondary markets, adding that its own reporters stood in line for 18 hours to get them. (There's a limit of six per household for the new online purchases.) Snap has said the glasses haven't been big money-makers, but TechCrunch thinks the new move is designed to show prospective IPO investors that they could be. The vending machines will go on hiatus for awhile, but they're expected to resurface eventually.

**Seven Men Charged in 2014 Hazing Death, Fraternity Sues for Name Misuse**

A total of seven men have been charged in connection with the 2014 hazing death of University at Albany student Trevor Duffy. The men allegedly forced Duffy to drink a 60-ounce bottle of vodka, leading to his death. The fraternity the men claim to be part of, Zeta Beta Tau (ZBT), has released a statement denying any affiliation with the group.

According to ZBT, the men were not part of the Epsilon Gamma Chapter, which is recognized by the university and the national fraternity. Instead, they were a separate group that used the ZBT name without authorization. ZBT has retained legal counsel and plans to sue the men for falsely representing themselves and damaging the fraternity's reputation.

The lawsuit claims that the men's unauthorized use of the ZBT name, symbols, and materials is a violation of United States Copyright and Trademark law. ZBT has stated that it will take legal action against anyone who uses its intellectual property without permission.

The seven men charged in connection with Duffy's death include Joseph Angilletta, who is being represented by Attorney Paul DerOhannesian. DerOhannesian has stated that his client's case is different from the new allegations brought by ZBT, and that he is not yet prepared to comment on the new lawsuit.

ZBT, which was founded in 1898 as the world's first Jewish fraternity, has chapters on over 90 campuses across North America and has more than 130,000 undergraduate and alumni brothers worldwide. The fraternity is seeking to protect its reputation and intellectual property from those who misuse its name and symbols.

The case highlights the dangers of hazing and the importance of holding individuals accountable for their actions. It also raises questions about the use of fraternity names and symbols, and the need for clear guidelines and regulations to prevent misuse.
details.ground_truth: The seven men accused of the 2014 hazing of a SUNY Albany student that caused his death are already in trouble with the school and the police. Now they've got a new problem on their hands: a lawsuit set to be filed by the fraternity whose name they apparently appropriated. Zeta Beta Tau's national office says the "rogue" group of SUNY Albany students charged in the death of 19-year-old Trevor Duffy used the frat's name without authorization and isn't linked to the actual recognized chapter on campus, NBC News reports. "Zeta Beta Tau is retaining counsel for the purposes of filing suit against these individuals who falsely represented themselves, deceiving the public and damaging the otherwise exceptional reputation of our Fraternity," a fraternity statement reads, per News10. Duffy died after allegedly being made to consume nearly half a gallon of vodka in a case that made headlines; his BAC was seven times the legal limit, notes NBC. The national fraternity says its intellectual property—including its name, the ZBT initials, and other materials—are protected under copyright rules, WRGB reports. That means anyone who falsely claims to be affiliated with the frat is fair game for legal action, a move the attorney for one of the accused says he's baffled by. "It's certainly novel, and I'm not sure why they'd take that step," the lawyer for Joseph Angilletta, one of two men arrested just last week in the case, tells the station. "Clearly one aspect here is they seem to want to distance themselves from this tragic event." (Five Baruch College frat members may face up to 20 years behind bars for allegedly taking part in the "glass ceiling.")
