**Nazi War Criminals: Recent Developments and Reactions**

In recent weeks, two high-profile Nazi war criminals have died, sparking reactions from governments, Jewish groups, and other organizations. Vladimir Katriuk, a 93-year-old Canadian resident of Ukrainian ancestry, died last week after a long illness. Katriuk was the second-most wanted man on the Simon Wiesenthal Centre's list of Nazi war criminals and was accused of participating in a village massacre in Belarus during World War II.

Katriuk's death comes just as Moscow was preparing a criminal case against him, which was seen as an attempt to embarrass Canada over its stance on Ukraine. The Russian government had called on Canada to extradite Katriuk to face trial for alleged war crimes, but Canada refused, citing its opposition to Russia's annexation of Crimea and interference in Ukraine.

Katriuk's case has been a contentious issue in Canada, with Jewish groups urging his deportation and the Ukrainian Canadian Congress calling for him to be left alone. In 1999, the Federal Court ruled that Katriuk obtained Canadian citizenship under false pretenses by not disclosing his collaboration with the Nazis, but found no evidence of atrocities committed by him. In 2007, the Harper cabinet decided not to revoke his citizenship.

Meanwhile, another Nazi war criminal, Gerhard Sommer, a 93-year-old former SS officer, has been cleared of charges due to his advanced dementia. Sommer was suspected of participating in a wartime massacre of civilians in Italy, but German prosecutors have shelved their investigation due to his inability to stand trial.

The Centre for Israel and Jewish Affairs has called on the Canadian government to take action on Katriuk's case, urging Ottawa to review the case and take necessary steps to ensure that if guilty, Katriuk be held accountable for war crimes committed in collaboration with the Nazi regime. The Ukrainian Canadian Congress, on the other hand, has urged Ottawa to ignore Russia's demands and leave Katriuk alone.

The deaths of Katriuk and Sommer highlight the ongoing issue of Nazi war crimes and the challenges of bringing perpetrators to justice, even decades after the fact.
details.ground_truth: There were two men at the top of this year's Simon Wiesenthal Center most-wanted Nazi war criminal list—and there is now no chance either one will face a court. No. 2 on the list, Ukrainian-born Vladimir Katriuk, has died in Quebec at the age of 93, the Toronto Star reports. Katriuk, who moved to Canada in 1951 and worked as a beekeeper for more than 50 years, was accused of being a "particularly active participant" in a massacre in what is now Belarus in 1943, when he was a member of an SS battalion that allegedly carried out many atrocities, the Guardian reports. Russia charged Katriuk with genocide last month, but Canadian authorities refused a request to send him to Moscow, citing Russia's actions in Ukraine, reports the Globe and Mail. Katriuk had long been under suspicion, but the wheels of justice did not move quickly: In 1999, Canadian authorities concluded he had entered the country under false pretenses, but in 2007 a decision to cancel his citizenship was overturned due to lack of evidence, the Star reports. The man at the top of the most-wanted list is also 93 years old. Gerhard Sommer is still alive in a Hamburg-area nursing home, but German prosecutors say they've dropped their investigation because he suffers from dementia and isn't fit to stand trial, the AP reports. In 2005, he was one of 10 former SS officers an Italian court found guilty of taking part in a massacre of 560 civilians in 1944, but German law didn't permit his extradition.

**Google CEO Sundar Pichai Receives $199 Million Equity Award**

Google's CEO Sundar Pichai has been granted an equity award valued at nearly $200 million, making him one of the world's highest-paid executives. The award, consisting of 273,328 Class C Google stock units, was valued at $199 million at the time of the grant on February 3. However, subsequent declines in Alphabet shares have reduced the current value to about $182 million.

The new award will vest in quarterly increments over the next four years as long as Pichai remains employed by Alphabet. This grant has lifted the value of Pichai's equity stake in Alphabet to over $600 million, still below the stakes held by co-founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin, and Eric Schmidt, Alphabet's executive chairman.

Pichai's award is one of the largest by a U.S. company, with Apple Inc. awarding Tim Cook a grant valued at about $376 million in 2011. The award has also sparked controversy, with critics pointing out that Google's effective tax rate is between 2% and 3%, compared to the UK's 20% headline corporation tax rate.

**Pichai's Net Worth and Comparison to Google's Founders**

Pichai's new shares bring his holdings in Alphabet to roughly $650 million, which is still far less than the net worth of Google's founders. Larry Page and Sergey Brin are worth $34.6 billion and $33.9 billion, respectively, according to Forbes. Eric Schmidt, Alphabet's executive chairman, holds shares worth $3 billion.

**Other Google Executives Receive Big Paydays**

Pichai was not the only Google executive to receive a big payday. Ruth Porat, Alphabet's chief financial officer, was handed shares worth about $38 million, on top of the $30 million signing bonus she received last year. Diane Greene, head of Google's cloud computing business, was awarded shares worth $42.8 million, in addition to the $148 million worth she was granted last year following Google's takeover of Bebop Technologies.

**Pichai Celebrates Award with Super Bowl and NFL Legend**

Pichai celebrated his award by watching the Super Bowl and meeting NFL legend Ronnie Lott. He tweeted about the experience, saying "Great game, even more so meeting a true NFL legend Ronnie Lott #SB50."
details.ground_truth: Google's parent company appears to be satisfied with how Sundar Pichai has performed during his four months as Google CEO, judging by the gargantuan $199 million equity award revealed in a securities filing. Alphabet stated that Pichai was awarded 273,328 Class C Google stock units on Feb. 3, bringing his holdings to around $650 million, reports the Wall Street Journal. The award makes Pichai the highest-paid CEO in America, according to the Guardian, which notes that Pichai's fortune is dwarfed by those of Google founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin, who are worth around $34 billion each, and by that of previous CEO Eric Schmidt, who's sitting on around $3 billion. (A former Google employee was awarded exactly $6,006.13.)

**Josh Hardy Receives Lifesaving Drug in Rare Medical Victory**

Josh Hardy, a 7-year-old cancer patient from Virginia, has been given a second chance at life after pharmaceutical company Chimerix agreed to provide him with a potentially lifesaving drug. The company had initially denied Hardy's family's requests for the medication, citing concerns that it would slow down efforts to get the drug on the market. However, after a nationwide campaign and intense media attention, Chimerix relented and agreed to provide the drug, brincidofovir, for Hardy's treatment.

Hardy, who is currently in critical condition at St. Jude Children's Research Hospital in Memphis, Tennessee, was diagnosed with a rare form of kidney cancer at just 9 months old. He has undergone multiple treatments and surgeries, but his condition has continued to deteriorate. The adenovirus infection he contracted after a bone marrow transplant has left him in heart and kidney failure, and his family had been desperate to find a way to save his life.

Chimerix's decision to provide the drug was made possible through a collaboration with the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), which expedited the clinical trial process. The company will now provide the drug to 20 patients in an open-label study, with Hardy being the first recipient. The FDA has also committed to working with Chimerix on the design of a pivotal Phase 3 study to further assess the drug's potential.

The campaign to save Josh Hardy's life has been a remarkable example of the power of social media and public pressure. Thousands of people took to social media to share Hardy's story and urge Chimerix to change its mind, with many organizations and charities joining in to support the family. The hashtag #savejosh trended on Twitter, and a Facebook page dedicated to the campaign attracted over 15,000 fans.

While Chimerix's decision to provide the drug is a major victory for Hardy and his family, it also highlights the complexities and challenges of the pharmaceutical industry. The company's initial refusal to provide the drug sparked a national debate about the ethics of compassionate use and the balance between profit and patient care.

In the end, Josh Hardy's story has brought attention to the need for more clinical development and research into the treatment of adenovirus infections. His family's determination and the public's outpouring of support have given him a second chance at life, and his case will continue to inspire hope and advocacy for patients and families facing similar challenges.
details.ground_truth: After a social media campaign—and an avalanche of bad publicity—a drug company has done a U-turn and agreed to give a dying 7-year-old boy an experimental drug that could save his life. The FDA allows "compassionate use"of unapproved drugs in such cases, but the Chimerix pharmaceutical company had insisted that giving the drug to Josh Hardy, who developed a bone marrow disorder after cancer treatment, would delay efforts to get it to market, CNN reports. Chimerix president Kenneth Moch says Josh will be the first patient in a pilot trial for the drug. "Being unable to fulfill requests for compassionate use is excruciating, and not a decision any one of us ever wants to have to make," says Moch, who tells the Fredericksburg Lance-Star that he and his employees have received death threats amid a flood of pleas to help the Virginia boy. Josh is expected to receive the drug within 48 hours, though his mother fears he is running out of time. "Even though he is frail, he has a very strong will about him," she tells Fox News. "But things just keep stacking against him, and we just want to do everything we can to give him the opportunity to make a full recovery."

**Actor Tom Sizemore Accused of Molesting 11-Year-Old Actress on Movie Set in 2003**

Actor Tom Sizemore, known for his roles in films such as Saving Private Ryan and Black Hawk Down, has been accused of molesting an 11-year-old actress on the set of the 2003 film Born Killers. The incident, which has never been publicly reported until now, allegedly occurred during a photo shoot for the film, where Sizemore, then 42, allegedly touched the girl's genitals.

According to multiple sources, including a dozen cast and crew members, Sizemore was sent home from the Utah set after the girl told her mother about the incident. However, months later, he returned for reshoots in Malibu after the girl's parents declined to press charges.

The girl, now 26, has recently hired a lawyer to explore legal action against Sizemore as well as her parents. Sizemore's agent, Stephen Rice, has declined to comment on the matter, stating "Our position is 'no comment.'"

The incident has sparked outrage among those who worked on the film, with many expressing shock and disgust at Sizemore's behavior. Production manager Cassidy Lunnen recalled that the girl was "so young it was unclear to her and [later] her parents what had actually taken place and if it was intentional or not."

Sizemore has a history of alleged aggressive behavior toward women, including convictions for battery and a recent plea deal for domestic abuse. He has also struggled with a long-standing addiction to drugs.

The film's producers, including Jai Stefan and Michael Manshel, have spoken out about the incident, stating that they removed Sizemore from the set as soon as they heard about the allegation and encouraged the girl's parents to contact law enforcement.

Sizemore's career has continued to thrive despite the allegations, with recent roles on TV shows such as Shooter and Twin Peaks. However, the latest accusations have sparked a renewed wave of criticism and outrage against the actor.

The incident has also raised questions about the handling of allegations of abuse in the entertainment industry, particularly in the wake of the Harvey Weinstein scandal. As one of the film's producers noted, "We took the allegation extremely seriously and we were willing to do anything, including dismissing Tom. We just couldn't be police, judge and jury."

The case serves as a reminder of the importance of taking allegations of abuse seriously and holding perpetrators accountable for their actions.

Multiple cast and crew members tell the Hollywood Reporter that Sizemore, best known for roles in war films including Black Hawk Down, was kicked off a Utah movie set in 2003 for allegedly touching an 11-year-old girl's genitals. They say the day after a Born Killers scene in which the girl sat on Sizemore's lap, she told her parents that he had touched her inappropriately, possibly putting his finger inside her. "At one point her eyes got just huge, like she could've vomited. I was watching her," co-star Robyn Adamson says. "Later, when I was told about what happened, I knew exactly what it was." Crew members say the girl's parents spoke to police, but ended up not pressing charges, possibly out of fear of ruining her film career. She is now 26 and says she is considering legal action against both Sizemore and her parents. Sizemore, 55, was dropped by his management firm soon after the incident. Former manager Charles Lago tells USA Today that he is "not surprised" by the allegations. "He's the most abhorrent person I've ever met in my life," Lago says.

**A Heartwarming Story of Love and Adoption**

In a remarkable tale of transformation, a former "classroom terror" has found a loving home and a new family. Cruz Riojas, now 45, was once a troubled student who frequently exhibited violent outbursts and was classified as a special education student. However, with the help of his teacher, Linda Hooper, Cruz's life took a dramatic turn.

In 1980, Hooper, a veteran elementary teacher, was warned about Cruz's reputation as a "holy terror." Despite her initial reservations, Hooper took Cruz under her wing and began to see beyond his troubled behavior. She discovered that Cruz was living in a one-room lean-to with his mother, stepfather, and five half-siblings, and was subjected to physical abuse.

Hooper's kindness and dedication eventually won Cruz over, and he began to open up to her. She started having him help with small tasks around the classroom and eventually at her home, where he would earn money for his efforts. Cruz's relationship with Hooper's husband, Gale, a firefighter, was particularly significant, as he had never had a positive male role model in his life.

details.ground_truth: Cruz Riojas came from a troubled home: He was reportedly beaten by his stepfather, lived in a decrepit one-room lean-to with six other family members, and wore the same clothes to school every day, according to the Lubbock Avalanche-Journal. But then an amazing thing happened: He started spending more time with Hooper, who would give him tasks to do around the classroom. He eventually began coming for visits at her home, where she lived with her husband and four daughters, often running the nearly eight miles between their two houses to get away from his stepfather. After an incident with his stepfather in 1983, Cruz’s mother asked if he could stay with the Hoopers for a few days till everything blew over. "He never left" after that, Hooper says. More than a decade later, he was still part of the Hooper family—but he wanted to make it official by asking the Hoopers to adopt him right before his 30th birthday. “He said he wanted to honor us, and it was a big honor," Hooper tells Today. "I’ve always known he loved me, but this really showed he loved us.” The adoption went through in 1998, but Cruz "was my son from the day I kept him,” Hooper says. Donald Trump has launched a new tirade against the media, calling it "disgusting" and blaming it for his drop in polls. **Groundbreaking Surgery Gives Boy Born Without Ears a New Lease on Life**

Nine-year-old Kieran Sorkin, born without ears and with a rare condition called microtia, has undergone a pioneering surgery at Great Ormond Street Hospital in London. The procedure, which involved creating a pair of ears from Kieran's own ribs, has given the boy a new sense of confidence and self-esteem.

Kieran, from Hertfordshire, was born deaf and had small lobes where his ears should be. However, thanks to previous surgery and a hearing aid, he can already hear. The surgery, led by consultant plastic surgeon Neil Bulstrode, involved harvesting cartilage from Kieran's ribs and shaping it into frameworks for his ears. The new ears were then grafted onto Kieran's head, with the help of a vacuum to shape the skin to the contours of the new ear.

The surgery, which took six hours to complete, has brought significant psychological benefits to Kieran. His father, David Sorkin, said that the boy's confidence has improved exponentially, and his performance at school has also improved. Bulstrode added that if you can change a young person's confidence, you can alter their whole trajectory in life.

Kieran's mother, Louise Sorkin, said that she wants her son to be accepted like everyone else, and that the surgery has given him a new sense of identity. Kieran himself said that he wants to be able to wear sunglasses and earphones like his friends, and that he's delighted with the result.

The surgery is not only a cosmetic procedure, but also a significant improvement in quality of life for children with microtia. Great Ormond Street Hospital performs about 40 of these operations each year, although most are to create one missing ear.

Advances in tissue engineering mean that this kind of reconstructive surgery could be done quite differently within a decade. Scientists at the Institute of Child Health, part of University College London, are creating stem cells from patients' fat tissue, which could be used to create new ears. However, this research is still in its early stages, and for the foreseeable future, children needing new ears will benefit from the same procedure used at Great Ormond Street Hospital.

Kieran will need a second operation in six months to make his ears stand out from the scalp more, but he's already delighted with the result. His father said that they couldn't have wished for a better result, and that Kieran's reaction was just a "wow
details.ground_truth: An operation in London has given 9-year-old Kieran Sorkin a pair of ears—made from his ribs, no less. Born deaf with no ears, Kieran was able to hear because of an implanted hearing aid, but he still wanted ears. "I want people to stop asking me questions," he told the BBC. "I'd like just to look like my friends. I'd also like to be able to wear sunglasses and earphones." So surgeons traced an outline of Kieran's mom's ears, removed cartilage from the boy's ribs, and sliced, contoured, and sewed the cartilage. Then they put it in two skin pockets and vacuumed them into the shape of ears. They don't perform any function, but Kieran's plastic surgeon says they can deliver a huge confidence boost: "If you can change the confidence of a patient at this young age, you can change their whole trajectory in life," he said. The ears should last, too, because they're made of cartilage rather than prosthetics, the Guardian reports. Every year about 100 British newborns lack one or both ears (it's called microtia), and the hospital Kieran went to performs the operation about 40 times a year. Scientists hope to one day make ears from the fat tissue of patients, instead of ribs. Kieran might have liked that, since he got so excited on seeing his new ears that he cried "Wow!" and giggled—which made his ribs hurt from the operation. **Wild Panda Attack Compensation and Conservation Efforts**

A Chinese man, Guan Quanzhi, has been awarded over $83,000 in compensation after being attacked by a wild panda in the northwestern province of Gansu. The incident occurred in March 2014 when the panda, which was being chased by other villagers, bit Guan's leg, requiring eight surgeries and potentially leaving him with a permanent injury that may require amputation.

Guan's son sued local forestry officials and the nearby Baishuijiang National Nature Reserve, which is home to over 100 wild pandas. Following negotiations, officials agreed to pay the compensation of 520,000 yuan ($83,000), which will cover Guan's medical bills.

The incident highlights the dangers of wild pandas, which are often perceived as harmless due to their lovable appearance. However, they are members of the bear family and have a fearsome bite, capable of inflicting serious injuries.

Despite the risks, wild pandas are a major tourist attraction in China, generating significant revenue for the country. Conservation efforts have also been successful, with the number of wild giant pandas increasing by nearly 17% over the decade to 2013 to reach 1,864, according to state media.

The giant panda's natural habitat lies in mountainous southwestern China, where they are under pressure from factors such as habitat loss. Conservation measures have been credited with the increase in their population, and efforts continue to protect these endangered animals.

The incident also serves as a reminder of the importance of respecting wildlife and their habitats. As the World Wildlife Fund (WWF) notes, "As cuddly as they may look, a panda can protect itself as well as most other bears," using its heavy weight, strong jaw muscles, and large molar teeth.

In conclusion, the compensation awarded to Guan Quanzhi is a significant step towards acknowledging the risks associated with wild pandas and the importance of protecting these endangered animals and their habitats.
details.ground_truth: Pandas may prefer their meals in the form of bamboo, but that doesn't mean their bite is toothless. A man in China recently received a harsh reminder of that after a wild panda bit his leg after authorities pursued the critter onto his lawn, reports AFP via Yahoo. The creature had made its way into a northwestern village, which is near a sanctuary that's home to about 100 wild pandas. "I saw a panda jump out in front of me, its body completely covered in mud," the man told local news. A struggle ensued, in which the bear wouldn't release the man's leg until a rescuer wrapped a coat around the animal's head. Finally, it fled—but not before causing injuries which, China Daily reports, led to eight surgeries over the past year and may lead to amputation. The man sued three government departments and won an $83,000 payout that will cover his medical costs, his lawyer says. (China Daily has a pretty gruesome photo of the injury.) "As cuddly as they may look, a panda can protect itself as well as most other bears," the World Wildlife Fund notes, per AFP. Indeed, panda attacks have led to some nasty consequences in the past.

details.ground_truth: Authorities are combing through more than 1,200 leads in a desperate search for a 9-year-old girl they say was abducted by her uncle May 4, WATE reports. According to the Knoxville News Sentinel, 57-year-old Gary Simpson picked Carlie Trent up from her Tennessee school, telling staff her father had been in an accident. Shortly before, he purchased a child's nightgown, bikini, girls' underwear, lipstick, and nail polish at an area Walmart. The Tennessee Bureau of Investigation has pictures of those items. Simpson also purchased camping supplies and nonperishable groceries, and authorities think he may be hiding with Carlie in an isolated area. The TBI says there have been rumors online that Simpson is trying to protect Carlie, but it says that couldn't be further from the truth. "This was not an innocent camping trip, this was a crime," a spokesperson tells WATE. Simpson, Carlie's uncle by marriage, and his wife once had custody of Carlie, but her father James Trent had custody at the time of her abduction. Shannon Trent, who hasn't had custody of Carlie in two years, says she "always had a bad feeling" about Simpson. "I should have stuck with my gut," she tells People. **CBS News Overhauls "The Early Show" with New Team**

In a bid to boost ratings, CBS News has made significant changes to its morning program, "The Early Show." The show's co-hosts, Harry Smith and Maggie Rodriguez, along with weather forecaster Dave Price, have been replaced by a new team.

Chris Wragge and Erica Hill, who have been co-anchoring the Saturday edition of the show since 2008, will take over as co-anchors of the weekday show starting January 3. Jeff Glor, who has been anchoring the network's Saturday newscast, will join the team as the regular news reader. Marysol Castro, a former weather anchor for ABC's "Good Morning America" weekend edition, will serve as the new weather anchor.

The changes come as the show continues to struggle in the ratings, consistently ranking behind NBC's "Today" show and ABC's "Good Morning America." Despite the shake-up, CBS News President Sean McManus expressed confidence in the new team, saying they have the right energy and chemistry to help the show grow.

Harry Smith, who had the longest tenure on the show, will remain at CBS News as a news reporter and primary substitute anchor for the "CBS Evening News," "Face the Nation," and "Sunday Morning." Smith, who has been with the show for 17 of the last 25 years, expressed gratitude for the opportunities he's had and wished the new team well.

The suddenness of the changes has raised some eyebrows, with veteran television critic David Bianculli calling it a "bloodbath" and suggesting that it may be a sign of desperation. However, CBS News is optimistic about the new team and believes they will help the show move forward.

The new team will debut on January 3, and it remains to be seen whether the changes will be enough to boost the show's ratings.
details.ground_truth: CBS is scrapping its Early Show team, replacing co-hosts Harry Smith and Maggie Rodriguez with the anchors of the show's Saturday edition, Chris Wragge and Erica Hill. Other more minor players also are leaving in the switch, which takes place early next year, the LA Times reports. The show has been consistently stuck in third place, well behind Today and Good Morning America. Smith, who survived the last major overhaul of the show in 2002, will stick with the network as Katie Couric's main backup on the CBS Evening News, notes AP. Click here for more.

George H.W. Bush, the 41st President of the United States, passed away at the age of 94. He led the country to a swift and decisive victory in the first Persian Gulf War and played a crucial role in the peaceful dissolution of the Soviet Union and unification of Germany. Bush's presidency was marked by a painful recession, which cost him a second term in office.

Born on June 12, 1924, in Milton, Massachusetts, Bush was the son of Prescott Bush, a successful Wall Street executive and U.S. senator from Connecticut. He joined the Navy at the age of 18 and became its youngest pilot, flying 58 missions in the Pacific during World War II. After the war, he married Barbara Pierce and began his business career in the oil industry, eventually co-founding Zapata Petroleum.

Bush's entry into politics began with his appointment as ambassador to the United Nations by President Richard Nixon. He later served as chairman of the Republican National Committee, envoy to China, and director of the CIA. In 1980, he ran for president but lost the nomination to Ronald Reagan. However, Reagan chose Bush as his running mate, and they won the election in 1988.

As president, Bush faced a series of challenges, including a recession and a primary challenge from Pat Buchanan. He abandoned his "no new taxes" pledge and signed a tax-raising measure, which led to a decline in his popularity. Despite this, Bush's approval rating approached 90% after the successful conclusion of the Persian Gulf War.

Bush's foreign policy achievements were significant, including the liberation of Kuwait from Iraqi occupation and the collapse of the Soviet Union. He also played a key role in the reunification of Germany and the peaceful dissolution of the Soviet Union.

In retirement, Bush remained active in public life, undertaking diplomatic missions and celebrating his birthday with a parachute jump. He developed friendships with former foes, including Bob Dole and Bill Clinton, and worked with Clinton on various projects, including tsunami and hurricane relief.

Throughout his life, Bush was known for his loyalty, integrity, and commitment to public service. He inspired generations of Americans to follow in his footsteps and leave a lasting legacy as one of the most respected and admired presidents in U.S. history.

O.J. Simpson, the former NFL star and actor, is set to appear before a Nevada judge on Thursday to make his case for parole. If granted, Simpson could be released from prison as early as October 1. Simpson has been serving a nine- to 33-year sentence for armed robbery and kidnapping charges stemming from a 2007 incident in Las Vegas.

Simpson's parole hearing comes nearly nine years after he was convicted of the crimes. He has been a model prisoner, according to his lawyer, and has expressed remorse for the incident. Simpson has also spoken to the victims and apologized for the incident, which he said got out of hand.

Simpson's past is marked by controversy, including his acquittal in 1995 of the murders of his ex-wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, and her friend, Ronald Goldman. He was later found liable for the murders in a civil trial and ordered to pay $25 million in punitive damages to the families of Simpson and Goldman.

Despite his past, Simpson's lawyer believes that he deserves parole. "He deserves parole. It's as simple as that," said Yale Galanter, one of Simpson's defense attorneys. Galanter also believes that the Las Vegas jury that convicted Simpson was motivated by anger over a book that Simpson co-authored called "If I Did It," which was seen as insensitive to the victims and their families.

Simpson's release from prison would be a significant development in his life, and it is likely to be met with a mix of emotions from the public. Some people will be happy to see him released, while others will be opposed to it.

In preparation for his release, Simpson has been working to improve his behavior and has spoken to the victims and apologized for the incident. He has also expressed a desire to reconnect with his family and friends and to live a quiet life.

However, some experts believe that Simpson's release from prison could be a mistake. "He just says, 'We'll be together again, my life will go back to normal,'" said Tom Scotto, a longtime friend of Simpson's. "Normal? There's never been such a thing for O.J. Simpson."

Simpson's release from prison would also raise questions about his ability to live a normal life. He has been in prison for nearly nine years, and it is unclear whether he is ready to re-enter society.

In conclusion, O.J. Simpson's parole hearing is a significant development in his life, and it is likely to be met with a mix of emotions
details.ground_truth: OJ Simpson's parole hearing in Nevada will be broadcast live at 1pm EDT Thursday and there's a strong chance that his path to freedom will be clear by the end of the afternoon. Nobody has registered to testify against the 70-year-old Simpson, who has been in prison for nine years on 12 convictions related to a Las Vegas robbery and will appear before the Nevada Parole Board via videolink, NPR reports. Thursday's hearing will cover four concurrent sentences for use of a deadly weapon and two consecutive sentences for assault with a deadly weapon, the Las Vegas Review-Journal reports. Four board members will vote after the hearing and Simpson could be free by Oct. 1 if they are all in favor of parole. If Simpson is indeed released this fall—which appears almost certainly to be the decision—it will "renew the rabid curiosity" in the case and "produce a spectacle unlike anything we’ve seen since he went behind bars," Nancy Armour at USA Today predicts. There has even been talk that Simpson might end up with a reality TV show, but Armour wants Simpson to avoid the spotlight unless he wants to return to the "toxic mentality that landed him in prison in the first place." If the former NFL star does end up with a TV show, the money is likely to go to the families of murder victims Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald Goldman, CBS News reports. He will still receive an NFL pension estimated at $25,000 per month.

**Jamaica Decriminalizes Small Amounts of Marijuana, Paves Way for Medical Cannabis Industry**

In a historic move, Jamaican lawmakers have passed legislation decriminalizing the possession of small amounts of marijuana, also known as "ganja" locally. The new law makes possession of up to 2 ounces (56.6g) of marijuana a petty offense, punishable by a fine rather than a criminal record. This change is expected to have a significant impact on the island nation, where marijuana has long been culturally entrenched but illegal.

The legislation also paves the way for the establishment of a licensing authority to regulate the cultivation and distribution of marijuana for medical, scientific, and therapeutic purposes. This move is seen as an opportunity for Jamaica to become a player in the nascent medical marijuana industry, health tourism, and the development of innovative pot-derived items.

Rastafarians, who have long used marijuana as a sacrament, will now be able to use it freely for religious purposes. Tourists who are prescribed medical marijuana abroad will also be able to apply for permits to buy small amounts of Jamaican weed.

National Security Minister Peter Bunting emphasized that the legislation does not mean Jamaica plans to soften its stance on transnational drug trafficking or cultivation of illegal plots. The security forces will continue to rigorously enforce Jamaican law consistent with international treaty obligations.

The move is part of an international trend of easing restrictions on marijuana for medical or personal use. More than 20 US states allow some form of medical marijuana, and several countries, including Uruguay and Argentina, have decriminalized or legalized marijuana.

Jamaica's commerce minister, Anthony Hylton, sees the cannabis industry as having "great potential" for the island, which is laboring under its latest loan program with the International Monetary Fund. Local scientists have already developed marijuana-derived products, such as "Canasol," which helps relieve pressure in the eyes of glaucoma patients.

The passage of this legislation is a significant step forward for Jamaica, which has long struggled with the issue of marijuana decriminalization. The law is expected to have a positive impact on the island's economy and society, and it marks a major shift in the country's approach to marijuana.

**Key Points:**

* Possession of up to 2 ounces (56.6g) of marijuana is now a petty offense, punishable by a fine rather than a criminal record.
* A licensing authority will be established to regulate the cultivation and distribution of marijuana for medical, scientific, and therapeutic purposes.
*

Jamaica has shied away from decriminalization because it didn't want to risk violating international treaties and provoking US sanctions, the Guardian reports. The process for the new law was described by National Security Minister Peter Bunting as an "elephantine," nearly 40-year effort, ABC Australia reports. "[The law] eliminates an unnecessary source of friction between police and citizens, and ensures that our young people are not gratuitously shackled with criminal records," he said in a statement. Jamaica also hopes to boost its health tourism and medical marijuana industries and make it a major player in the pot product market, the Guardian notes. International exporting, however, remains a no-no. A US counternarcotics official told the AP in an email that "Jamaican law is of course Jamaica's own business," but warned that drug trafficking into the US is still illegal.

**AirAsia Flight 8501 Crash: Search Efforts Continue**

On December 28, 2014, AirAsia Flight 8501, an Airbus A320-200, crashed into the Java Sea while en route from Surabaya, Indonesia to Singapore, resulting in the loss of 162 lives. The search and rescue efforts have been ongoing for nearly a week, with multiple countries and agencies involved.

**Search Efforts**

Indonesian search teams have found four large parts of the plane on the sea bed, including a 18-meter-long piece that appears to be part of the jet's body. The objects were detected using sonar equipment and were confirmed to be from the missing plane. Divers have not been able to enter the waters due to strong currents and big surf, but officials are hopeful that they will find many of the passengers and crew still strapped in their seats inside the plane.

**Cause of the Crash**

The cause of the crash remains unexplained, but bad weather appears to have been a factor. A 14-page report by Indonesia's Meteorology, Climatology and Geophysics Agency suggests that the plane was trapped in bad weather that would have been difficult to avoid. The report also mentions the possibility of icing on the plane's engines, which could have been caused by the bad weather.

**Investigation**

The investigation into the crash is ongoing, with autopsies to be carried out on some of the bodies, including the pilot and co-pilot. Aviation experts say that the more passengers, luggage, and parts of the aircraft that remain intact, the more likely the plane hit the water in one piece, which would indicate problems like a mechanical error or a stall instead of a mid-air breakup.

**AirAsia's Response**

AirAsia has been reviewing the suspension of its flights from Surabaya to Singapore, which was announced by Indonesian authorities due to the airline not having a permit to fly on Sundays. However, Singapore's Civil Aviation Authority has said that from its end, the airline had been approved to fly the route daily.

**Relatives' Reaction**

Family members of the victims have been waiting anxiously for news of their loved ones. Some have expressed hope that the discovery of the plane's wreckage will lead to the recovery of more bodies. "Let's hope the news is true," said Ongko Gunawan, whose sister was on the flight with her husband and their child. "We need to move on."

**International Response**

The search and rescue efforts have involved multiple countries and agencies
details.ground_truth: Search teams in Indonesia may have found the main fuselage of the AirAsia plane where most of the remaining victims and the plane's black boxes are expected to be. Authorities found "four big parts of the plane we're looking for," says the official in charge of the search in the Java Sea, reports Reuters. The biggest of the pieces is about 59 feet long and 18 feet wide, reports AP. The pieces have only been detected, not recovered, and divers hope conditions will permit them to reach the objects tomorrow. So far, only 30 of 162 bodies have been recovered, and most of the victims are believed to be still strapped in their seats. Authorities also said today that AirAsia was in violation of its license by flying to Singapore on a Sunday, the day of the crash, reports the Telegraph. As a result, the airline might have its license revoked in Indonesia. There's still no conclusions yet in what caused the crash, but theories continue to center on stormy conditions. "Flight 8501 appears to have been trapped in bad weather that would have been difficult to avoid," says a report by Indonesia's Meteorology, Climatology and Geophysics Agency.

**Internet Archive Aims to Fix Broken Links on the Web**

The Internet Archive, a non-profit organization dedicated to preserving online content, has launched a new initiative to address the issue of broken links on the web. The project involves archiving web pages as they are created and referencing the pages they link to, ensuring that even if the original page is removed or changed, a link to the archived version remains intact.

The goal of this effort is to provide a permanent record of web pages and their intended links, allowing users to access the original content even if the link is broken. This is particularly important for websites that are no longer active or have been taken down, as it preserves the historical context and information that was once available.

The Internet Archive is working with "No More 404" sites, which are websites that have pledged to preserve their content and provide links to archived versions of their pages. By partnering with these sites, the Internet Archive aims to create a comprehensive archive of web pages and their links, ultimately fixing broken links on the web.

This initiative has the potential to greatly improve the online experience, making it easier for users to access information and preserving the historical record of the web.
details.ground_truth: The Telegraph reported yesterday on a crazy court case in the UK: After a pregnant Italian woman, in town for business, had a panic attack, social service workers in Essex got a court order allowing the woman to be forcibly sedated and undergo a C-section so they could take her baby. Fifteen months later, the little girl is still with social service workers, who won't return her to her mother. The case is now "an international legal row," the Telegraph says, and the anonymous woman's lawyers call it "unprecedented." The woman was in Britain in July 2012 for an airline training course, and called police when she suffered the panic attack. They arrived while she was on the phone with her mother, who told police the woman suffered from bipolar disorder and was off her medication, according to a Telegraph columnist. Police took her to a psychiatric facility, and restrained her under the Mental Health Act when she said she wanted to go back to her hotel. She underwent the C-section after having been there five weeks. The case is ongoing; the mother says she has made a full recovery, but a judge nonetheless ruled that her daughter should be put up for adoption. More on the case here and here.

**Habeas Corpus: A Fundamental Right Under Threat**

Habeas corpus, a cornerstone of Western law, has been a vital safeguard against government overreach and abuse of power. This ancient legal procedure, enshrined in the US Constitution, ensures that individuals cannot be detained indefinitely without a valid reason. However, recent developments have raised concerns about the erosion of this fundamental right.

**Guantanamo Bay and the Military Commissions Act**

In 2006, the Military Commissions Act (MCA) revoked the right to habeas corpus for detainees at Guantanamo Bay and foreign nationals labeled "enemy combatants." This provision applies to US citizens and legal residents, potentially leaving them vulnerable to indefinite detention without due process. The MCA has been criticized for its ill-considered and dangerous provisions, which undermine the rule of law and the principles of justice.

**The Case of Guantanamo Detainees**

The majority of Guantanamo detainees were sold into captivity by warlords for bounties, with little or no evidence against them. Despite numerous legal victories affirming their right to challenge their detention, the Bush administration has prevented them from receiving a fair hearing in court. The Supreme Court has agreed to hear the detainees' cases for the third time, with the hope of upholding habeas corpus and holding the administration accountable.

**Nonhuman Rights Project and the Case of Hercules and Leo**

In a groundbreaking decision, a New York judge granted a pair of research chimpanzees, Hercules and Leo, the right to have their day in court through a writ of habeas corpus. This ruling marks the first time an animal has been covered by a writ of habeas corpus in US history, recognizing chimpanzees as legal persons. The Nonhuman Rights Project, which filed the case, hopes to use this victory to sway judges in other jurisdictions and ultimately secure the right to bodily liberty for cognitively complex animals.

**Implications and Future Directions**

The erosion of habeas corpus threatens not only the rights of Guantanamo detainees but also the fundamental principles of justice and democracy. The case of Hercules and Leo highlights the need to reevaluate our treatment of nonhuman animals and recognize their autonomy and dignity. As the Nonhuman Rights Project continues to push for the rights of animals, it is essential to defend the right to habeas corpus and uphold the rule of law.

**Conclusion**

Habeas corpus is a vital safeguard against government overreach and abuse of power. The recent developments at Guantanamo Bay and the case of Hercules and Leo serve as a reminder of the importance of
details.ground_truth: The writ of habeas corpus lets prisoners appear in court to make their captors justify why they're being held. Until now in the US, those who've used this legal tactic have been human. But a New York judge yesterday ruled that the writ may be used by two lab chimpanzees at Stony Brook University, Science magazine reports. NY Supreme Court Justice Barbara Jaffe ordered a university rep to address a suit filed by the Nonhuman Rights Project by appearing in court May 6 to argue why the college is holding Hercules and Leo. The group, which says the animals are being detained for biomedical experiments, says its ultimate goal is to have the animals released to the Save the Chimps sanctuary in Fort Pierce, Fla., per the NhRP's website. "This is a big step forward to getting what we are ultimately seeking: the right to bodily liberty for chimpanzees and other cognitively complex animals," Natalie Prosin, the project's executive director, tells Science. The case kicked off in December 2013 with lawsuits that also included two chimps held on private property; each case was struck down, sending the NhRP down the appeals path. Not everyone's convinced the upcoming hearing will mean liberation for the chimps. A Pepperdine University law professor tells Science that the judge likely just wants to hear both sides of the story: "It would be quite surprising if the judge intended to make a momentous substantive finding that chimpanzees are legal persons" without doing so, he notes. Prosin, meanwhile, says her group isn't stopping with the chimps and will also target the release of other animals. (Click to read about what chimps talk to each other about.)

A violent shooting on the Las Vegas Strip early Thursday morning left three people dead and at least six injured. The incident occurred when a black Range Rover opened fire on a Maserati, causing it to crash into a taxi that burst into flames. The taxi driver and passenger were killed, along with the driver of the Maserati. The passenger in the Maserati was shot and taken to the hospital for treatment.

According to police, the shooting was sparked by an altercation at a nearby hotel, which spilled onto the streets. The Range Rover and Maserati were seen speeding down Las Vegas Boulevard, with the Range Rover firing gunshots at the Maserati. The Maserati then crashed into the taxi, which exploded in a fireball.

The Range Rover was last seen heading north from the scene, with police contacting authorities in three neighboring states to be on the lookout for the vehicle. The SUV was described as a four-door vehicle with big black rims and paper dealer plates from out of state.

The incident marked the latest in a series of violent incidents on the Strip since the beginning of the year. Two people were critically wounded in a shooting at a parking garage on February 6, and a tourist was stabbed in an elevator at The Hotel at Mandalay Bay.

The investigation is ongoing, with police collecting evidence and interviewing witnesses. The incident has raised concerns about safety on the Strip, but police have reassured visitors that the area is generally safe and that they have made arrests or identified suspects in each of the recent violent incidents.

A 16-year-old girl, Autumn Veatch, has survived a small-plane crash in the rugged North Cascades mountains of Washington state. Veatch, who was traveling with her step-grandparents, Leland and Sharon Bowman, of Marion, Montana, was presumed dead after the plane failed to arrive at its destination on Saturday afternoon. However, on Monday, Veatch was found alive and taken to an Okanogan County hospital with minor injuries.

According to Veatch's account, the plane crashed in the mountains, and she was left alone after her step-grandparents did not survive the impact. Veatch, who had little outdoor training, used her wits to survive for two days in the wilderness. She followed a drainage down to a river, then the river downstream to the nearest road, where she caught a ride with hikers to the nearest community, Mazama, and contacted authorities.

Veatch's survival was a miracle, and her family and friends were overjoyed to hear the news. Her father, David Veatch, said he was "incredibly relieved" to hear that his daughter was alive. The search for the plane's wreckage continued on Monday, with authorities using Veatch's description of the crash site to narrow down the search area. Five aircraft equipped with special radios searched the mountains, while ground crews focused on areas between Mazama and Rainy Pass. The crashed plane crossed the Idaho-Washington border on Saturday afternoon, but it dropped off the radar near Omak, Washington, about an hour later.

Veatch's ordeal has been described as an "epic survival tale," and her bravery and resourcefulness have inspired many. Her story is a testament to the human spirit and the power of survival in the face of adversity.

details.ground_truth: A 16-year-old girl in Washington state is bruised and dehydrated but very much alive after surviving a plane crash and a long trek through what authorities describe as some of the state's most rugged terrain. Autumn Veatch was on a small plane with her step-grandparents that crashed after departing Kalispell, Mont., on Saturday afternoon, the Bellingham Herald reports. There was no sign of the plane or its occupants until a motorist found Veatch on State Route 20 yesterday afternoon and took her to a general store, where employees called authorities, the AP reports. She was hospitalized with minor injuries. Her father tells the Herald that after the plane crashed into a mountain, it caught fire and she was unable to get her step-grandparents out. She spent about a day near the plane waiting for rescue before following a stream and then a trail out of the woods, her father says. Friends say both father and daughter are completely overwhelmed. "She did joke that it was a good thing she'd watched all those Survivor shows that she didn't like, but her dad made her watch anyway," a family friend tells the Seattle Times. Authorities are still searching for the missing Beech A-35. (In Colombia last month, a mother and baby survived four days in the jungle after a plane crash.)

**Environmental Regulation Collides with Music Industry: Gibson Guitar Raids**

In a rare case of environmental regulation intersecting with the music industry, the Gibson Guitar Corporation has been raided by federal marshals in Tennessee. The raids, which occurred in August 2011, are believed to be related to the company's alleged trafficking in illegally obtained wood, specifically ebony from Madagascar.

The Lacey Act, a century-old endangered species law, was amended in 2008 to include plants as well as animals. The law requires end users of endangered wood to certify the legality of their supply chain all the way to the trees. The Environmental Investigation Agency (EIA) has concluded that Gibson knowingly imported tainted wood, despite being aware of the risks involved.

Gibson CEO Henry Juszkiewicz claims that the company has been unfairly targeted and that the government has not provided clear evidence of wrongdoing. He argues that the company has complied with U.S. and Malagasy law and that the recent raid seized legally obtained wood from India.

However, the EIA's Andrea Johnson defends the Lacey Act and the government's efforts to enforce it. She argues that the law is necessary to reduce illegal logging and send a signal to the markets that responsible sourcing of wood is essential.

The Gibson raids have sparked concerns among other guitar builders, who fear that the Lacey Act is burdensome and retroactive. Attorney Ronald Bienstock warns that the law may require guitar owners to prove the provenance of wood acquired decades ago, and that owners may be asked to account for every wooden part of their guitars when re-entering the U.S.

The case highlights the complexities of environmental regulation and its impact on industries that rely on natural resources. As the government prepares to charge Gibson, the company's fate remains uncertain, and the music industry waits with bated breath to see how the case will unfold.

**Related News:**

* The Internet Archive's Wayback Machine has been collecting data from Alexa Internet since 1996, providing a valuable resource for researchers and historians.
* The Lacey Act has been amended to include plants as well as animals, and requires end users of endangered wood to certify the legality of their supply chain.
* The Environmental Investigation Agency has concluded that Gibson knowingly imported tainted wood, despite being aware of the risks involved.
* The Gibson raids have sparked concerns among other guitar builders, who fear that the Lacey Act is burdensome and retroactive.
* The case highlights the complexities of environmental regulation and its impact on industries that rely on natural resources.
details.ground_truth: Allegations of illegal wood imports prompted the Justice Department to raid Gibson Guitar facilities in Tennessee last week. NPR aired the complicated story involving the 100-year old Lacey Act, which prohibits imports of endangered species, including plants, into the US. No formal charges have been pressed, but it appears the issue lies with Gibson possibly importing banned Madagascar ebony. Gibson insists the wood confiscated by marshals was legally acquired rosewood from India. Adding some gusto to the story, right-leaning sites assert that Gibson rival CF Martin uses the same wood in some of its guitars, but the company was never investigated. The Landmark Report thinks that's fishy, given that Martin's CEO is a Democratic donor and Gibson's CEO is a GOP backer. Raising the octave even higher, it is possible Michelle Obama ran afoul of the Lacey Act when she presented France's Carla Bruni with a Gibson guitar that may have contained banned wood. However the story plays out, many are frustrated with the retroactive aspect of the law. "It's a nightmare," says a dealer. "I can't help it if they used Brazilian rosewood on almost every guitar made prior to 1970."

**Escalating Conflict in Gaza and Israel**

A severe escalation of violence has been witnessed in the Gaza Strip and Israel, with both sides trading rocket fire and airstrikes. The conflict began on Wednesday, with Israel launching a military operation, dubbed "Pillar of Defense," aimed at deterring Hamas from launching cross-border attacks. The operation has resulted in the deaths of at least 30 Palestinians, including 13 militants and 16 civilians, and three Israeli civilians.

**Israel's Military Campaign**

Israel's military has been conducting airstrikes and artillery attacks on the Gaza Strip, targeting suspected rocket-launching sites and Hamas personnel. The Israeli military has reported that it has hit over 600 targets in Gaza, including rocket-launching sites, tunnels, and command centers. The military has also mobilized tens of thousands of troops, with convoys of buses and tanks heading towards the Gaza Strip.

**Hamas' Response**

Hamas has responded to the Israeli military campaign with a barrage of rocket fire, with over 300 rockets launched at Israel since the conflict began. The rockets have caused damage and injuries in several Israeli cities, including Tel Aviv and Kiryat Malachi. Hamas has also claimed responsibility for firing a rocket towards Jerusalem, which landed in the occupied West Bank.

**International Response**

The international community has been watching the conflict with growing concern. The United States has called on countries with ties to Hamas to urge the group to stop its rocket attacks. The United Nations has also condemned the violence, with the Nonaligned Movement calling for "decisive action" by the UN Security Council. Egypt, which has a peace treaty with Israel, has also been involved in efforts to calm the situation, with Egyptian Prime Minister Hisham Kandil visiting Gaza and calling for a truce.

**Egypt's Role**

Egypt's new President, Mohamed Morsi, has been actively involved in efforts to calm the situation, with his prime minister leading a delegation to Gaza. Morsi has also called for a truce and has vowed to support the Palestinians. The Egyptian government has also recalled its ambassador to Israel and delivered a formal protest to the Israeli government.

**Casualties and Damage**

The conflict has resulted in significant casualties and damage on both sides. At least 30 Palestinians have been killed, including 13 militants and 16 civilians. Three Israeli civilians have also been killed, with dozens more injured. The conflict has also caused significant damage to infrastructure and property in both Gaza and Israel.

**Future Prospects**

The future prospects for the conflict are uncertain
details.ground_truth: A brief, planned ceasefire failed to materialize in Gaza today, as death continued to rain down on the strip. Israel had offered to hold its offensive to accommodate a visit from Egyptian Prime Minister Hesham Kandil, provided Hamas held its fire as well. But Hamas said it would keep firing, and one Israeli defense minister complained that 50 rockets had flown in from Gaza during Kandil's visit, CNN reports. A Hamas-run TV station reported that Israel had kept firing as well, but Israel says it took a break for at least two hours. In Palestine the death toll has risen to 21, including 13 civilians, Reuters reports. Among those civilians were seven children and a pregnant teenager. Israel's death toll held steady at 3, despite the hundreds of rockets fired into Israel. But Hamas did up the ante by firing rockets near Tel Aviv for the first time. Air-raid sirens sounded (the last time they did so was during the Gulf War) and civilians ran for cover, though the missiles exploded harmlessly, with one going into the sea. "There will be a price for that escalation," Ehud Barak vowed, according to the New York Times. Israel has now hit 250 Gaza targets, while taking further steps toward a ground invasion, calling up 16,000 reservists, the Wall Street Journal reports. It's also steadily sending troops and armored vehicles to the border, notes CNN—between 1,500 and 2,000 are already there, one official said. Israel claims the attacks have weakened Hamas' military capabilities and caused its attacks to lighten, but Hamas denied that, saying it had hit multiple Israeli targets today. Kandil emerged from his meeting with Hamas expressing solidarity, saying the new Egyptian regime would be more active in helping the Palestinians. "The time has changed," he said. "No longer the Israeli occupation will be able to carry out their attacks against the Palestinians without being held responsible. That time is far bygone." For its part, the Obama administration says it's seeking help from Arab countries in calling on Hamas to relent. "The onus rests squarely on Hamas ... to stop its rocket attacks," says a State Department spokesman. UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-Moon is planning diplomatic visits to Jerusalem, Ramallah, and Cairo within days.

**Rabies Outbreak in Maine: Recent Attacks and Precautions**

A recent surge in rabies cases in Maine has left residents on high alert. In the past few weeks, several people have been attacked by rabid animals, including a woman who was bitten by a raccoon while jogging in Hope, Maine.

**Attack in Hope, Maine**

On June 3, 21-year-old Rachel Borch was attacked by a rabid raccoon while running in the woods near her home. The raccoon, which was acting aggressively and erratically, bit Borch's thumb and began to scratch her arms and legs. In a desperate bid to defend herself, Borch drowned the raccoon in a puddle of water, holding its head underwater until it stopped struggling.

**Rabies Outbreak in Maine**

According to the Maine Center for Disease Control, there have been 20 animals that have tested positive for rabies in 2017, including raccoons, red foxes, and skunks. This is a significant increase from 2016, when 64 animals tested positive for the disease.

**Precautions and Prevention**

Maine animal control officer Heidi Blood warns that if one animal tests positive for rabies, it's "almost 100 percent" certain that there are other animals in the area also infected. Blood advises people and their pets to avoid animals that are acting aggressively or erratically, even if they appear to be dead, as the rabies virus can live outside the body for 24 hours.

**Vaccination Requirements**

Under Maine law, cats and dogs, even if they stay indoors, must be vaccinated against the disease. Blood emphasizes the importance of vaccination and encourages people to take precautions to prevent the spread of rabies.

**Recent Attacks**

In addition to Borch's attack, a Wiscasset man was bitten on both hands by a suspected rabid fox in Topsham earlier this week. Borch has received six shots, including the rabies vaccine, and is expected to receive her last injection this weekend. She has been taking antibiotics for the puncture wounds on her hands.

**Conclusion**

The recent surge in rabies cases in Maine serves as a reminder of the importance of taking precautions to prevent the spread of the disease. Residents are advised to be aware of their surroundings and to avoid animals that are acting aggressively or erratically. By taking these precautions, people can help prevent the spread of rabies and keep themselves and their pets safe.
details.ground_truth: Rachel Borch was out for a jog in the woods near her home in Hope, Maine, when a "ferocious-looking" attacker with beady eyes and tiny teeth made a beeline for her, reports the Camden Herald. Borch, 21, knew immediately that something was wrong with the raccoon that was charging toward her. "Imagine the Tasmanian devil," she tells the Bangor Daily News of the "terrifying" June 3 incident. Yanking out her headphones, she began "dancing" around the animal on the narrow path, but she tells the Herald she knew that, one way or another, the animal was going to bite her. She figured her hands would be the best spot, so she offered them up. The raccoon chomped down on her thumb and stayed there, scratching at her legs and arms as she screamed. Now on her knees, she spotted her phone lying submerged in a mud puddle, and had an idea: drown it. "With my thumb in its mouth, I just pushed its head down into the muck," she tells the News. When the raccoon finally stopped moving, she yanked out her finger and raced the three-quarters of a mile home. Two days later, the state confirmed the animal was infected with rabies. Borch got rabies shots, and an animal control officer adds an unpleasant footnote: The infected raccoon may not be alone. "Not to scare people," Heidi Blood tells the News, but "when there’s one, there’s typically another." (Normally nocturnal like raccoons, a crazed beaver attacked a woman paddle-boarder.)

**Ancient Mars: A Wet and Habitable Planet**

Recent studies have revealed that Mars was once a warm and wet planet, with a massive ocean covering nearly half of its northern hemisphere. NASA scientists have used infrared maps to analyze the Martian atmosphere and found that the planet lost a vast amount of water in the past, equivalent to more than six times that now locked up in the planet's frozen ice caps.

The ocean, which lasted for millions of years, was at least a mile deep in places and held 20 million cubic kilometers of water, more than the Arctic Ocean. The scientists believe that the water pooled into a much deeper ocean in the low-lying northern plains, creating an ocean that covered nearly a fifth of the planet's surface.

The study, published in the journal Science, used data from three of the most powerful infrared telescopes in the world to analyze the Martian atmosphere over six years. The researchers found that water near the Martian ice caps is enriched with deuterium, a heavy isotope of hydrogen, indicating that Mars must have lost a vast amount of water in the past.

The findings suggest that Mars was habitable in the distant past, with long-standing bodies of water, lakes, deltas, and perhaps even seas. The search for life on Mars will ramp up in 2018 with the European Space Agency's Exomars rover, which will look for chemical signatures of life, perhaps emanating from microbes living deep beneath the Martian soil.

Astronomers have also determined that an ocean at least a mile deep covered a significant fraction of the Martian surface four billion years ago. The evidence comes from an analysis of the water vapor that lingers today in the Martian atmosphere, which revealed the chemical composition of the atmosphere's vapor.

The study suggests that the ancient sea once covered a fifth of the planet's surface, and that the water would have reached a depth of about 450 feet (137 meters) if it had covered the entire planet evenly. However, the true amount of water that pooled on the ancient surface of Mars may have been much larger.

The findings continue to mount that Mars was once far wetter and warmer than it is today, and that the ancient chemical environment was hospitable to biology. This means that support for the notion that life might once have existed on Mars is only getting stronger.

**Key Findings:**

* Mars had a massive ocean covering nearly half of its northern hemisphere four billion years ago.
* The ocean was at least a mile deep in places and held 20 million cubic kilometers of
details.ground_truth: Imagine all the water in the Arctic Ocean. Now, imagine all that and more on Mars. If you visited the Red Planet roughly 4.3 billion years ago, that's what you likely would have found, say NASA scientists. Their new study arrived at that "solid estimate ... by determining how much water was lost to space," says lead author Geronimo Villanueva. The Guardian reports the scientists used three powerful infrared telescopes to analyze two forms of water in Mars' atmosphere: H2O and HDO, in which deuterium (aka "heavy" hydrogen) has taken the place of one hydrogen atom. As National Geographic explains, Mars' gravity is weaker than our own; that allowed hydrogen to escape from the atmosphere and into space over time, boosting the amount of deuterium in its water. Scientists compared the ratio of HDO to H2O in Martian water today with that in water from a 4.5 billion-year-old Mars meteorite to arrive at their conclusions, a press release states. They ultimately calculated that Mars was once home to 20 million cubic kilometers of ocean. It could have covered every inch of the planet in water 450 feet deep, but the scientists think a different scenario is more likely: that the ocean covered roughly a fifth of the planet, was located in the northern hemisphere, and was as much as a mile deep. While National Geographic observes the findings back up "reams of earlier evidence that water once existed on the surface" of Mars, another study author points out the assessment of the degree of water lost indicates something new. "The planet was very likely wet for a longer period of time than was previously thought, suggesting it might have been habitable for longer," a scientist says. (Mysterious plumes on Mars are stumping scientists.)

**Rescue Mission: Swedish Professor Helps Save Student and Family from ISIS**

In a remarkable story of courage and determination, Swedish professor Charlotta Turner helped rescue her graduate student Firas Jumaah and his family from the clutches of ISIS in Iraq in 2014. Jumaah, a member of the Yazidi minority, had been working on his PhD at Lund University in southern Sweden when he received a text message from his wife, warning him of the growing violence in their home country.

Jumaah had initially stayed behind to complete his lab work, but when he returned to Iraq for a family wedding, he found himself in the midst of a deadly conflict. His family was facing a life-and-death situation, and Jumaah sent a desperate text message to his supervisor, asking her to remove him from the doctoral program if he wasn't back in Sweden within a week.

Professor Turner, who was shocked by the message, called Jumaah and discovered the gravity of the situation. She quickly sprang into action, contacting the university's security chief, Per Gustafson, who arranged for a rescue operation. Over a few days, Gustafson hired a security company, which then arranged for a team of heavily-armed mercenaries to extract Jumaah and his family from their hiding place in a disused bleach factory.

The rescue mission was a success, and Jumaah and his family were safely evacuated to Erbil Airport, where they were reunited with Jumaah's wife and two small children. The family has since settled in Sweden, and Jumaah has completed his PhD and now works for a pharmaceuticals company in Malmö.

The rescue operation was a unique event, with no other university involved in a similar mission. Gustafson described it as a "unique event" and praised Turner's determination and courage in helping to save Jumaah and his family.

Turner's actions were motivated by her concern for her student's safety and her outrage at the actions of ISIS. "What was happening was completely unacceptable," she said. "I got so angry that IS was pushing itself into our world, exposing my doctoral student and his family to this, and disrupting the research."

The story of Jumaah and his family's rescue is a testament to the power of human kindness and determination in the face of adversity.
details.ground_truth: Four years ago, a chemistry professor got a text from her grad student: If I'm not back in a week, cut me from the doctoral program. Charlotta Turner called him right away: "He was very sad and crying,” the 48-year-old prof at Lund University in Sweden tells NBC News. "I could hear that the situation was hopeless and they had to flee." The student, Firas Jumaah, was visiting his native Iraq to help family members during a brutal 2014 ISIS attack targeting Yazidis—a religious minority that includes his family. The terror group had just enslaved and massacred Yazidis by the thousand in nearby Sinjar. Now Jumaah and family were planning to flee to the mountains. "I had no hope at all," says Jumaah, per the Local. "I was desperate." But Turner took action. She spoke to Lund University's then-security chief, who contacted a company that sent mercenaries into northern Iraq. Only days later, four armed mercs on two Landcruisers blazed into the place where Jumaah was hiding, and rushed him to Erbil Airport with his wife and two young kids. "I have never felt so privileged, so VIP," he says. "But at the same time I felt like a coward as I left my mother and sisters behind me." Seeing his colleagues back in Sweden, he was speechless: "I just cried," he says. Yet Jumaah finished his PhD and found work at a Malmo pharmaceuticals company, and his family survived. The bill: roughly 60,000 kroner ($6,613), which his family has nearly finished paying. “If they told me to pay 200,000 kronor, I would,” says Jumaah. (The UN is finding fresh ISIS horrors.)

A brazen jewelry store robber, described as a white woman in her 20s or 30s, 5-foot-8 and 130 pounds, has been linked to six robberies across the Southeast since April. "Focus" is a caper film directed by John Requa and Glenn Ficarra, starring Will Smith and Margot Robbie. The movie follows the story of Nicky Spurgeon, a veteran con man, and his young apprentice, Jess Barrett. The film's plot revolves around their elaborate cons, which take them to various locations, including casinos, racetracks, and football games.

The movie has received mixed reviews from critics, with some praising its charm and wit, while others have criticized its absurdity and lack of emotional depth. Mick LaSalle, a movie critic for The San Francisco Chronicle, wrote that the film is "ridiculous in every detail" and that its con is that it's showing a secret underworld, but it's not doing any of those things. However, he also noted that the film has some scattered good moments, including a scene where Will Smith and Margot Robbie are in a VIP box at a football game, making small bets with each other.

The casting of the movie was a significant challenge, with several actors, including Ryan Gosling, Brad Pitt, and Ben Affleck, being considered for the lead role. The female lead was also a subject of much speculation, with actresses such as Jennifer Lawrence, Emma Stone, and Kristen Stewart being rumored for the part. Ultimately, the role went to Margot Robbie, who was chosen for her charm and wit.

Will Smith's performance in the movie has been praised for its charm and charisma. He plays the role of Nicky Spurgeon, a con man who is confident and persuasive. The movie's writers, Ficarra and Requa, have said that they wanted to let Smith be himself in the role, and he has delivered a performance that is reminiscent of his earlier work in movies such as "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air" and "Men in Black."

The movie's success can be attributed to its lighthearted and playful tone, which is reminiscent of classic caper films such as "The Lady Eve" and "The Sting." The film's R rating allows for some raunchy wit and humor, which adds to its charm. Margot Robbie's performance as Jess Barrett has also been praised for its charm and wit, and she has been compared to a modern-day Grace Kelly.

details.ground_truth: Will Smith stars as Nicky, an established con man who takes on a new apprentice, Australian newcomer Margot Robbie's Jess, in Focus. They both love the con game, but who's playing who? Here's what critics are saying: Richard Corliss at Time is a fan. "The mix of longtime star and minx on the rise is one tasty element in the success of a movie that approaches the modest goals and effortless allure of a 60-year-old Hitchcock," he writes. Smith "takes a welcome break from glowering sci-fi roles" and writer-directors Glenn Ficarra and John Requa "deserve some credit in letting Will be Will in the star's first charm barrage since 2005's Hitch." Steven Rea at the Philadelphia Inquirer admits Smith "shows some of the movie-star wattage that's been missing from his recent pics. He charms." There's also "combustible chemistry" between Smith and Robbie, but the movie just "disappoints," Rea writes. "Even if you're willing to forgive its sinkhole plotholes and farthest-fetched conceits, the film ... ultimately makes no sense." Betsy Sharkey, on the other hand, says this "rom-com-con" is "an irresistible reminder of all the reasons we first fell for the Fresh Prince so many years ago." Writing at the Los Angeles Times, she notes the romantic role of Nicky fits Smith perfectly, while Robbie is "more than holding her own" as his match. "The scams are Rubik's Cube complicated, but what keeps you guessing is whether the romantic connection between Jess and Nicky is real or just another con." But Mick LaSalle at the San Francisco Chronicle isn't convinced. In a review titled "Will Smith just stole $12 from your pocket," he argues Focus is "ridiculous in every detail. It's a movie with no truth that teaches nothing and shows nothing, that has only its audacity to recommend it." Nicky and Jess lack "impact," partly because "Smith is not a strong leading man," he says. Viewers are left "waiting for the trick, which is not the same as being fooled."
