**Convicted White-Collar Criminal Receives Additional Jail Time for Staged Insurance Scam**

Shannon Egeland, a 43-year-old convicted white-collar criminal, has been sentenced to an additional three years and 10 months in jail for his role in a staged insurance scam. Egeland, who was already serving a 10-year federal prison term for his involvement in a mortgage fraud case, orchestrated the scam to delay his prison sentence and benefit from a disability insurance policy.

In 2014, Egeland directed his 17-year-old son, Rylan, to shoot him in the leg with a shotgun along a roadside in Caldwell, Idaho. The shooting was staged as a way to claim disability benefits, and Egeland had applied for the policy just seven days earlier, falsely claiming he had never been arrested or indicted for a felony or misdemeanor in the past 10 years.

The scam backfired, and Egeland's left leg was amputated as a result of the gunshot. He has since been taking three mental health-related medications and has expressed remorse for his actions, stating that the pain is on his son and that he wishes he could take it all back.

Prosecutors described Egeland as a "menace to society" and a "self-absorbed, opportunistic narcissist" motivated by greed. They also noted that Egeland's actions caused "unimaginable" psychological and emotional destruction to his minor child.

Egeland's defense lawyer argued that he was suffering from a "perfect storm" of medical and mental health issues and financial difficulties at the time of the shooting, and that he already faces a lengthy sentence that will be a challenge for him.

The judge ordered Egeland to pay the $90,011 he owes in child support and urged him to get mental health treatment and counseling while in prison. Egeland will also be required to submit to a new mental health evaluation when he gets out of custody.

This additional sentence brings Egeland's total jail time to 13 years and 10 months, a result of his guilty plea to conspiracy to commit wire fraud in the insurance scam and interstate failure to pay child support.
details.ground_truth: A white-collar crook is facing extra prison time for having his son shoot him in the legs with a 20-gauge shotgun, the BBC reports. Shannon Egeland, 43, was already facing 10 years for taking part in a vast mortgage-fraud scheme when he had his 17-year-old son shoot him by a road in Caldwell, Idaho, in an attempt to avoid prison. "The psychological and emotional destruction defendant caused this minor child is unimaginable," US attorney Scott Bradford wrote in a sentencing memo. Back in 2009, Egeland was co-owner of an Oregon development company that defrauded banks out of $20 million in loans that he and a partner used to fund a lavish lifestyle. Facing prison, Egeland took out disability insurance and had his son aim for his legs. Egeland told police he'd been attacked after stopping to assist a pregnant driver, but investigators got suspicious when his pricey BMW, his wallet, and his cellphone weren't taken, the Idaho Statesman reports. Then they learned about his recent insurance, and the whole thing unravelled. Now Egeland is facing an extra 3 years and 10 months for his roadside scheme and had his leg amputated from the shotgun blast. Bradford called him a "self-absorbed, opportunistic narcissist," the Oregonian reports, but Egeland—who is now on three medications for mental health—has cast his own judgment. "What bothers me the most is my son—the pain is on him,'' he says. "If I could take it all back, I would, but I can't. That will haunt me the rest of my life.''

**Tesla Autopilot Crash Investigation: A Summary of the News**

A fatal crash involving a Tesla Model X occurred on March 23rd, killing the driver, Walter Huang, a 38-year-old Apple engineer. The incident has sparked an investigation by the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) and raised concerns about the safety of Tesla's Autopilot system.

According to Tesla, the vehicle was on Autopilot with adaptive cruise control engaged when it crashed into a barrier on the 101 Highway near Mountain View, California. The company stated that the driver had received several visual and one audible hands-on warning earlier in the drive, but the driver's hands were not detected on the wheel for six seconds prior to the collision.

The investigation has revealed that the crash attenuator, a highway safety barrier designed to reduce impact, had been crushed in a prior accident without being replaced. Tesla blamed the severity of the crash on this factor, stating that they have never seen this level of damage to a Model X in any other crash.

Huang's family has come forward, stating that he had complained to the dealership about the vehicle's Autopilot system veering towards the same barrier on multiple occasions. His brother, Will, said that Walter had taken the car to the dealership seven to 10 times to address the issue, but they were unable to duplicate the problem.

The California Department of Transportation (CalTrans) has released a statement saying that replacement work was scheduled for the damaged barrier, but storms had delayed the fix. The previous accident that damaged the barrier occurred 11 days before Huang's fatal crash.

Tesla has defended its Autopilot system, stating that it "unequivocally makes the world safer for the vehicle occupants, pedestrians and cyclists." The company also pointed out that its data shows that Tesla owners have driven the same stretch of highway with Autopilot engaged roughly 85,000 times since Autopilot was first rolled out in 2015, with over 200 successful Autopilot trips per day on this exact stretch of road.

The incident has raised concerns about the safety of autonomous vehicles and has come under increased scrutiny following a fatal crash involving an Uber autonomous vehicle in Tempe, Arizona. Arizona's governor suspended Uber's license to test autonomous vehicles on public roads last week.

In a statement, Tesla expressed its condolences to Huang's family and friends, stating that the company is working closely with investigators to understand what happened and what can be done to prevent similar incidents in the future.
details.ground_truth: The Tesla Model X that slammed into a highway barrier in California last week and killed the 38-year-old Apple engineer at the wheel had been on autopilot at the time of the crash, Tesla confirms in a blog post. But the company says driver Walter Huang "received several visual and one audible hands-on warning earlier in the drive," adding that "the driver’s hands were not detected on the wheel for six seconds prior to the collision." Tesla also laid some blame on state highway officials, asserting that "the reason this crash was so severe is because the crash attenuator, a highway safety barrier which is designed to reduce the impact into a concrete lane divider, had been crushed in a prior accident without being replaced." The fact that the vehicle was on autopilot is likely to be controversial because, as ABC News notes, driver Huang had reportedly been concerned about it. His brother told KGO that Huang had brought his Model X back to the dealership complaining that when he used the feature, the car kept swerving toward the very same barrier that it eventually struck in the fatal collision. The NTSB is investigating the crash, including the fire that broke out after the collision. The accident follows another in Arizona in which a self-driving Uber struck and killed a pedestrian.

**Robin Williams: A Legacy of Joy and Genius**

Renowned actor and comedian Robin Williams, 63, passed away on Monday, leaving behind a legacy of unforgettable performances and a profound impact on the entertainment industry. Williams' death has sent shockwaves across the globe, with fans and fellow celebrities mourning the loss of a true genius.

Born to entertain, Williams began his career as a stand-up comedian, captivating audiences with his lightning-fast wit, incredible impressions, and boundless energy. His early days at the Comedy Store on Sunset Boulevard showcased his unique talent, and his subsequent rise to fame with the hit TV show "Mork & Mindy" cemented his status as a household name.

Williams' filmography is a testament to his versatility and range, with iconic roles in "Good Morning, Vietnam," "Dead Poets Society," "The Fisher King," and "Good Will Hunting," for which he won the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor. However, it was his work in children's films that truly endeared him to a new generation. Movies like "Aladdin," "Mrs. Doubtfire," and "Hook" showcased his ability to bring joy and wonder to audiences of all ages.

Williams' impact on popular culture extends beyond his filmography. He was a true original, a master of improvisation, and a brilliant observer of human nature. His stand-up routines were a testament to his boundless creativity and his ability to connect with audiences on a deep level.

As a person, Williams was known for his generosity, humility, and kindness. He was a true friend to many, and his passing has left a void in the lives of those who knew him. His legacy will continue to inspire and entertain future generations, and his memory will live on through the countless lives he touched.

In the words of a fellow comedian and friend, Williams' death is a tragic reminder of the fragility of life and the importance of seeking help when needed. As the world mourns the loss of this incredible talent, we are reminded of the power of comedy to bring us together, to make us laugh, and to remind us of the importance of living in the moment.

Rest in peace, Robin Williams. Your legacy will live on forever.
details.ground_truth: After Robin Williams' sudden death, the tributes are rolling in, with many recalling a comic genius grappling with private challenges. A sampling: When it comes to comedy, "there wasn't a faster brain on the planet," writes Tony Hicks in the Contra Costa Times. We'll be hearing "a litany of tributes about one of the great comedians who ever lived. Much of it will be some of the same adjectives used when any great performer dies—especially before their time. But in Williams' case, most of it will be true." Early in his career, "it was clear that Mr. Williams was one of the most explosively, exhaustingly, prodigiously verbal comedians who ever lived," AO Scott writes in the New York Times. And beyond that, "his essential persona as an entertainer combined neediness and generosity, intelligence and kindness, in ways that were charming and often unexpectedly moving." Williams may have gotten his start long before Aladdin, but he gave a "generous and humble" gift to the millennial generation, writes Daniel D'Addario at Salon. "Williams will be remembered for his edgy comedy and for dramatic turns, but for people my age, Williams was our childhood," from Mrs. Doubtfire to Jumanji to Flubber. In the Los Angeles Times, Kenneth Turan recalls a moment when, facing an onslaught of photographers, Williams asked him—in the voice of a fly from a 1950s sci-fi flick—to "help me, Ken. Help me." The experience stuck with him and seems particularly resonant today, he writes.

**Murder Suspect Remains on the Run in Montpelier**

A murder suspect, Jayveon Caballero, 29, is still at large after a weekend shooting in Montpelier, Vermont, that left a former Vermont Frost Heaves basketball player, Markus Austin, 33, dead. According to police, Caballero and Austin were friends and had been out together at a bar in Barre when a fight broke out. The altercation continued outside Austin's apartment, where Caballero fatally shot Austin.

**Investigation and Search Efforts**

Police have issued an arrest warrant for Caballero on a charge of second-degree murder, with a bail set at $500,000. Authorities believe Caballero may have boarded a Greyhound bus in White River Junction on Sunday morning, heading to New York City, but it is unclear if he got off at any intermediate stops. The police are reaching out to other states for assistance in locating Caballero.

**Witness Accounts and Previous Incidents**

A witness, Jeff Sarpong, reported seeing Caballero shoot Austin and then show sympathy for him. Another witness stated that Caballero's girlfriend, Desiree Cary, 22, was involved in the altercation at the bar and was assaulted by Austin. Caballero's girlfriend was taken into custody on Sunday evening on charges unrelated to the shooting, including selling crack cocaine and heroin.

**Background and Previous Incidents**

Caballero's apartment has been the site of previous problems, including drag racing and constant traffic. Neighbors have reported dealing with issues from the property in the past. The police raided Caballero's apartment early Monday morning but found no one there.

**Historic Significance**

The shooting death of Austin marks the first murder in Montpelier in almost a century, with the last recorded murder occurring in the 1920s. Montpelier has a population of approximately 7,500 residents, making it the nation's least populous capital.

**Current Status**

The search for Caballero continues, and authorities are asking anyone with information about his location or the shooting to contact the Vermont State Police.
details.ground_truth: Police in the country's smallest state capital are investigating something that hasn't happened there in living memory: a murder. Police in Vermont say they have issued an arrest warrant for 29-year-old Jayveon Caballero, who is accused of fatally shooting Markus Austin in Montpelier early Sunday after an altercation, the Times Argus reports. Witnesses told investigators that Austin, 33, assaulted Caballero’s girlfriend, Desiree Cary, during the altercation outside a bar in the nearby city of Barre early Sunday. Police say Caballero later confronted Austin outside his apartment and shot him dead. The body was found in the parking lot of Austin's apartment complex. A Vermont State Police spokesman says Caballero, who knew Austin before the shooting, fled the town and probably the state after the shooting, WCAX reports. The police spokesman says Caballero is believed to have boarded a Greyhound bus bound for New York City on Sunday morning, which made numerous stops in other states along the way. Later Sunday, Cary, 22, was arrested on apparently unrelated charges of selling heroin and crack cocaine. With around 7,500 residents, Montpelier has the smallest population of any state capital, the AP notes. Police Chief Anthony Facos says this is the city's first murder since a woman shot her husband in the 1920s.

On January 31, 2018, a rare celestial event will take place, offering a unique opportunity for skywatchers around the world. The Super Blue Blood Moon Total Lunar Eclipse will be visible from eastern Asia, across the Pacific to western North America, and will be the first total eclipse of a Blue Moon in nearly 152 years.

**What is a Blue Moon?**

A Blue Moon occurs when there are two full moons in a single month. This happens because the lunar cycle and the calendar year are not perfectly synchronized, resulting in an extra full moon. The January 31 Blue Moon will be the second full moon of the month, making it a rare and special event.

**Supermoon and Lunar Eclipse**

The January 31 Super Blue Blood Moon Total Lunar Eclipse will be a total eclipse, with the moon slowly losing its brightness and taking on a reddish hue due to the Earth's atmosphere bending the light. The eclipse will be visible from eastern Asia, across the Pacific to western North America, and will be the first total eclipse of a Blue Moon in nearly 152 years.

**Viewing the Eclipse**

The best time to view the eclipse is right after moonrise and before sunrise, when the moon is sitting on the horizon. The moon will appear its biggest and brightest due to a "moon illusion" effect. The eclipse will begin at 11:48am UTC and reach its maximum at 1:30pm UTC.

**Livestream and Photography**

The Virtual Telescope project will provide a livestream of the eclipse from Australia, beginning at 11:30am UTC. For photography, NASA recommends using a daylight white balance and adjusting the exposure slider to get the right balance of light. Putting the moon in context of a local landmark can also help create an original shot.

**History and Rarity**

The last total eclipse of a Blue Moon occurred on March 31, 1866. The next total eclipse of a Blue Moon will occur on December 31, 2028, and January 31, 2037. The Super Blue Blood Moon Total Lunar Eclipse on January 31, 2018, is a rare and special event that should not be missed.

details.ground_truth: Look up at the sky on Jan. 31 and you may witness a sight unseen for 150 years. For the first time since 1866, a total lunar eclipse will occur with the blue moon, or second full moon of the month, which—like the one visible on New Year's Day—will also be a supermoon. Got all that? When the moon is at or near the closest point to Earth in its orbit (aka, a supermoon), it appears 14% bigger and 30% brighter than full moons that occur at the farthest point in the moon's orbit, though the moon will lose brightness as it enters Earth's shadow, according to NASA. Because of the way Earth's atmosphere bends light, the eclipsed moon will take on a reddish hue, something often referred to as a blood moon, making this rare celestial event "a super blue blood moon eclipse," according to the Miami Herald. The next blue moon eclipse won't occur until 2028. The eclipse will last for 3.5 hours, with the total eclipse stretching for 77 minutes, reports Sky & Telescope. Those along the Pacific Rim from Alaska and northwestern Canada to central and eastern Asia, Indonesia, New Zealand, and Australia will get the best view of totality during the middle of the night. However, partial phases of the eclipse should be visible under a clear sky in central North America, western Asia, India, the Middle East and eastern Europe, per Space.com. North American viewers should look up as the moon sets on the morning of Jan. 31, while those on the opposite side of the world should see a partial eclipse as the moon rises. Not in an ideal viewing area? The Virtual Telescope plans to livestream the total eclipse from Australia, which you can watch here, per Quartz. (Bogus glasses damaged a solar eclipse viewer's eyes.)

**Syrian Protests Escalate: US Ambassador Visits Hama, Thousands Protest Across Country**

The situation in Syria continues to deteriorate as protests against the government of President Bashar al-Assad intensify. In a significant development, US Ambassador to Syria Robert Ford visited the embattled city of Hama on Thursday, where he met with residents and visited a hospital treating wounded protesters. The visit was seen as a show of support for the Syrian people's right to peaceful demonstrations.

Ford's delegation did not include any official Syrian "handlers," and Syrian authorities allowed him to pass through checkpoints to reach the town. The US State Department said that Ford's visit was intended to "make absolutely clear with his physical presence that we stand with those Syrians who are expressing their right to speak for change."

The visit came as thousands of Syrians took to the streets across the country, with over 500,000 protesters flooding through Hama on Friday, according to activists. The opposition reported 13 protesters killed, including five deaths in the central city of Homs, two in the capital's commercial neighborhood Midan, and six in the Dumair area, east of Damascus.

The protests followed a visit to Hama by French Ambassador Eric Chevallier, who also showed support for the residents. Damascus accused Washington of "interfering" in its affairs, with the Syrian Foreign Ministry saying that Ford's visit was "clear evidence of the United States' involvement in current events in Syria and its attempt to incite an escalation in the situation, which disturbs Syria's security and stability."

Meanwhile, an estimated 1,000 Syrians have fled Hama in fear of another military crackdown on protests calling for Assad to quit and an end to the Baath Party's decades-long grip on power. The London-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights said that security forces have killed at least 23 civilians in the town of Salamiyah, where the residents had evacuated to.

The situation in Hama remains tense, with reports of killings and arrests continuing. Al-Watan, a state-run newspaper, said that the situation in Hama was calm, but this has not been confirmed by other sources. The city has been a symbolic center of opposition since the 1982 crackdown on a revolt by the banned Muslim Brotherhood against then-president Hafez al-Assad, father of the current leader.

The US State Department has summoned the Syrian ambassador for talks this week after reports that embassy staff had filmed US protests against the crackdown in Syria. The situation in Syria continues to deteriorate,
details.ground_truth: America's ambassador to Syria visited one of the cities worst-hit by the crackdown against anti-government protesters yesterday, reports CNN. Robert Ford went to the city of Hama "to make absolutely clear with his physical presence that we stand with those Syrians who are expressing their right to speak for change," an embassy spokeswoman says. An estimated 500,000 people joined an anti-government rally in the city last Friday. The Syrian government accused Ford of going to the city without authorization, saying the visit is "clear evidence of the US involvement in the ongoing events in Syria and its bids to aggravate the situations which destabilize Syria.'' An embassy spokeswoman says the Syrian government was told a delegation would be visiting Hama, although no Syrian "handlers" were taken and officials weren't informed about the ambassador's presence. The city has been a symbol of opposition since 1982, when a crackdown ordered by the present Syrian leader's father killed around 20,000 people, al-Jazeera notes.

**Election Security Concerns: Recent Hacking Attempts and Foreign Meddling**

The recent hacking attempts and foreign meddling in the US election system have raised concerns about the vulnerability of the electoral process. The Democratic National Committee (DNC) was the target of a sophisticated hacking attempt, which was later revealed to be an unauthorized "simulated phishing test." However, the incident highlights the ongoing threats to election security.

According to officials, the hacking attempt was designed to gather usernames and passwords that would allow access to the party's database. The fake login page was created to trick people into handing over their login details, and the DNC believes it was designed to breach the party's most sensitive information.

The incident is part of a larger trend of foreign and domestic manipulation of the electoral process. Microsoft has detected that hackers tied to Russian intelligence targeted the Senate and conservative think tanks in the United States, creating fake websites to gather information. Facebook has also identified disinformation efforts targeting people around the world.

Experts warn that the cyber age has changed elections forever, with many systems vulnerable to manipulation. From voter-registration systems in the 50 states to the inner workings of the parties, the opportunities for foreign and domestic manipulation are numerous.

As the midterm elections approach, political groups and government organizations are on high alert for new hacks and foreign meddling. The White House cybersecurity coordinator, Rob Joyce, has stated that the focus has shifted from using the cyber realm to steal secrets to using it to impose national power.

The FBI is investigating the incident, and officials are urging vigilance to prevent future attacks. The Democratic National Committee's chief security officer, Bob Lord, has called the voter file "the party's most sensitive information" and emphasized the need to remain vigilant in the face of constant threats.

Overall, the recent hacking attempts and foreign meddling highlight the need for increased security measures to protect the electoral process and prevent manipulation by foreign and domestic actors.
details.ground_truth: The FBI is reportedly investigating a sophisticated—but unsuccessful—attempt to hack into the Democratic National Committee's voter database. The DNC learned of the attempt on Tuesday, CNN reports. The attack, which was detected by a cloud service provider and a security research company, involved a fake login page intended to gather usernames and passwords for a service called Votebuilder, which hosts the DNC's voter database. It's a method called "spearphishing," according to the New York Times. "It was very convincing," Mike Murray of the cybersecurity firm Lookout tells CNN, adding that it would be tough to tell the real page from the fake one, even if they were side-by-side. The fake login page was ultimately removed by the cloud hosting company DigitalOcean. The company's chief security officer says the threat was identified before the attack was launched. "We see no evidence that any sensitive data was stolen," he says. A DNC official tells the Times that it is not clear who the hackers were in this case. But, the paper recalls, a 2016 hack of the DNC was ultimately traced to Russia. This latest attempt, DNC Chief Security Officer Bob Lord tells the Times, "is further proof that there are constant threats as we head into midterm elections and we must remain vigilant in order to prevent future attacks." Earlier this week, Microsoft reported that it had uncovered new Russian hacking attempts targeting conservative organizations in the US.

On April 15, 2013, two explosions rocked the finish line of the Boston Marathon, leaving a trail of destruction and death in its wake. The bombings resulted in the loss of three innocent lives, including an 8-year-old boy, Martin Richard, and two adults, Krystle Campbell and an unidentified Boston University graduate student from China.

**Victims**

* Martin Richard, 8, from Dorchester, was killed in the bombing. His mother, Denise, and 7-year-old sister were seriously injured.

* The third victim, a Boston University graduate student from China, was identified on Tuesday evening. The student's name and gender have not been released pending family approval.

The city of Boston was placed on high alert, with a strong police presence on the streets and a firm resolve to heal and move forward. Mayor Thomas Menino promised that the city would not be intimidated by terror and would "pull together" in the face of tragedy.

The FBI announced that there were no known additional threats, and officials vowed to "go to the ends of the Earth" to find those responsible for the bombings.

The nation and the world came together to offer support and solidarity to the victims and their families. President Obama praised first responders and others who helped the injured, saying that America's response to evil is "selflessly, compassionately, unafraid."

Pope Francis sent a message of condolence to Cardinal Sean O'Malley, archbishop of Boston, and prayed for the dead, the suffering, and those engaged in the continuing work of relief and response.

**Return to Normalcy**

As the city began to heal, there were small signs of a return to normalcy. Planes, trains, and automobiles were running at or near normal operating schedules, and some runners took recovery runs to work out the kinks.

details.ground_truth: Another fatality in the Boston bombings has been identified: The family of 29-year-old Krystle Campbell says she was killed as she and a friend were cheering on another friend who was racing, reports WCVB. We also ask for your patience and for privacy as we work to simultaneously grieve and recover. Thank you." The third victim was a grad student at Boston University, but the person's identity is being withheld until the family says it's OK to release, reports USA Today.

**Global Obesity Epidemic: A Growing Concern**

A recent study published in the Lancet medical journal has revealed a staggering 2.1 billion people worldwide are either obese or overweight, accounting for nearly 30% of the global population. The study, conducted by researchers at the University of Washington's Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation, analyzed data from 188 countries from 1980 to 2013 and found that obesity rates are rising in both rich and poor nations.

**The United States: A Leader in Obesity**

The United States leads the world in obesity, with 13% of the global obese population, despite having only 5% of the world's population. The country has seen a significant increase in obesity rates, with about one-third of adults being overweight and another third being obese.

**Global Obesity Rates**

The study found that obesity rates are highest in the Middle East and North Africa, with over 58% of adult men and 65% of adult women being overweight or obese. Other countries with high obesity rates include:

* Bahrain, Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Oman, and Kuwait, where more than 50% of adults are overweight or obese
* New Zealand, Bahrain, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, and the United States, where men have high obesity rates
* Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Oman, Honduras, and Bahrain, where women have high obesity rates

**Children and Adolescents**

Obesity is also a growing concern among children and adolescents, with rates rising nearly 50% worldwide. In developed countries, men have higher obesity rates, while in developing countries, women have higher rates.

**Causes of Obesity**

The study suggests that the availability of cheap, fatty, sugary, salty, high-calorie "junk food" and the rise of sedentary lifestyles are major contributors to the global obesity epidemic. The World Health Organization has launched a commission to study rising obesity among children worldwide and suggest solutions.

**Consequences of Obesity**

Obesity is a major risk factor for heart disease, stroke, diabetes, arthritis, and certain cancers. Chronic complications of weight kill about 3.4 million adults annually, according to the U.N. World Health Organization.

**Conclusion**

The global obesity epidemic is a growing concern that requires immediate attention. The study highlights the need for a comprehensive approach to address the root causes of obesity, including the availability of unhealthy food and sedentary lifestyles. By working together, we can reduce the burden of obesity and promote healthier lifestyles worldwide.
details.ground_truth: There are more obese or overweight people in the world today than there were people of any weight in 1935, the most comprehensive look at worldwide obesity in decades warns. The 188-country study found that there are 2.1 billion overweight or obese people in the world, making up around 30% of the world's population, up from 20% in 1980, USA Today reports. Not a single country has recorded a decline in obesity over the last 30 years. "We hoped there would be some examples of success that you could latch onto," a study co-author says. "But there's a complete lack of success stories in bringing down obesity." The study published in British medical journal the Lancet found that the Middle East and north Africa had seen the biggest weight gains, though the US still has the largest number of obese people, with 87 million of the world's 671 million obese people, reports Reuters. Other countries, however, have even higher obesity rates, including Tonga, where more than 50% of all adults are obese. "Two-thirds of the obese population actually resides in developing countries," says one of the researchers; they warn that obesity rates are rising among rich and poor countries, men and women, and adults and children alike.

**Weekly News Summary**

This week's news highlights several interesting stories across various categories. 

**Celebrity News**

The most talked-about celebrity news this week revolves around Tom Cruise and his ex-wife Katie Holmes. According to reports, Tom Cruise has written an emotional letter to Katie Holmes, attempting to rekindle their friendship, if not more. The letter, which was written after 12 months of separation, is said to have been a shock to Katie, but she has reportedly been "genuinely touched" by Tom's words. The couple divorced in July last year after Katie filed for divorce, citing reasons that Tom ignored the signs of their troubled marriage. Despite the letter, sources close to Katie say she is not interested in reuniting with Tom and is instead focusing on building a new life for herself in New York City with their daughter Suri.

Overall, this week's news covers a range of topics, from celebrity gossip to fashion trends and technology.
details.ground_truth: It's been a year since Katie Holmes filed for divorce from Tom Cruise, and apparently Cruise is feeling sentimental. A source tells UK magazine Look the actor sent Holmes an "emotional letter" looking to, at the very least, be friends again, Australia's News Network reports. "It's like he's finally recognized that Katie will always be the love of his life," the source says. Even so, "It won't have been an over the top letter—it has been a year and I'm sure Tom will have been aware that Katie wouldn't be interested in running straight back into his arms." Sources close to Holmes say she was "touched" by the letter, which doesn't sound promising for Cruise. "Tom would no doubt take her back in a second, but I don't think that's what Katie wants," says one. (Just to keep things in perspective, we'll point out that Look is the sort of magazine that also runs headlines like, "Royal Bodyguard Warns: 'Kate Middleton's Baby Is In Danger!'") In other news, Huffington Post notes that it's Cruise's 51st birthday.

**Canadian Billionaire Barry Sherman and Wife Honey Found Dead in Toronto Mansion**

Less than a week before their bodies were discovered, Barry Sherman and his wife Honey were making plans for their annual trip to Florida. However, their vacation was cut short when they were found dead in their Toronto mansion on Friday. The couple, both 75 and 70 years old, were discovered hanging from a railing surrounding their basement lap pool.

According to Toronto police, the cause of death was ligature neck compression, meaning strangulation. The homicide squad is now leading the investigation, although police initially classified the deaths as "suspicious" rather than a homicide.

The couple's family has dismissed the theory that the deaths were a murder-suicide, calling it "inconsistent with the rumours regrettably circulated in the media." Friends and colleagues of the Shermans have also expressed shock and disbelief at the suggestion.

Barry Sherman was a renowned businessman and philanthropist, with a net worth estimated at $4.77 billion, making him the 15th-richest person in Canada. He founded Apotex, a generic pharmaceuticals giant, and was known for his dedication to his work. His wife, Honey, was a dedicated philanthropist and member of several boards, including the Baycrest Foundation and the York University Foundation.

The couple's friends and colleagues have described them as kind and generous, and have expressed their shock and sadness at their deaths. Toronto Mayor John Tory and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau have also paid tribute to the couple.

As the investigation continues, police have not found any signs of forced entry or suspects-at-large. The couple's real estate agent discovered their bodies, and there was no note left behind to explain what had happened.

The community is still reeling from the news, with a makeshift memorial set up in front of the couple's home. Friends, employees, and well-wishers have been dropping off flowers in honour of the Shermans.

The investigation is ongoing, and police are working to determine the circumstances surrounding the couple's deaths.
details.ground_truth: The investigation into the mysterious deaths of a billionaire and his wife is now being led by homicide detectives, police say—suggesting the deaths of Barry and Honey Sherman were either murder-suicide or a double murder. Police, who have described the deaths as "suspicious," revealed Sunday that the cause of death for both Shermans was "ligature neck compression," a form of strangulation, the CBC reports. Sources have told the media that the couple were found hanging near an indoor pool in the basement of their Toronto mansion. Police say they haven't found any sign of forced entry, or a note that could explain what happened to 75-year-old pharmaceutical tycoon Barry Sherman and his 70-year-old wife, both renowned philanthropists. The couple's four children have rejected what they say are "rumors" that the deaths are being investigated as a murder-suicide, and many of the influential couple's friends agree. "There is absolutely zero debate in my mind, this was a double homicide," says Canadian Sen. Linda Frum, a longtime friend of the couple, per the New York Times. The Globe and Mail reports that just days before the bodies were found, Honey Sherman was enthusiastically making plans for their annual trip to Florida, emailing friends that she would be traveling to the state on Dec. 18 and Barry Sherman would join her a week later. The couple also sent out invitations last week to a dinner party at their winter home in Palm Beach.

**Egypt's Parliamentary Elections and Hosni Mubarak's Trial: Key Developments**

Egypt is in the midst of a significant transition, with the country's first parliamentary elections since the ouster of former President Hosni Mubarak in February 2011. The final round of voting took place on January 3, 2012, with the Muslim Brotherhood's Freedom and Justice party expected to consolidate its gains and potentially win a majority of seats in the new parliament.

The Brotherhood's party has been leading in the polls, with estimates suggesting it has won nearly 50% of the seats allocated in the first two rounds of voting. The party's leader, Essam el-Erian, has downplayed the possibility of winning a majority, but analysts believe it is a strong possibility. The Brotherhood has stated its intention to form a coalition government, but winning a clear majority would enable it to govern without forming an alliance.

The elections have been marked by controversy, with the military rulers facing growing opposition from protesters who demand an earlier end to military rule. The ruling generals have said they will not cede power before presidential elections are held by the end of June. The new parliament is expected to take authority over the hiring and firing of a prime minister, but the military rulers have said they intend to retain control.

Meanwhile, Hosni Mubarak's trial has resumed, with the chief prosecutor accusing the ousted leader of imposing "tyrannical rule" and devoting the last decade of his rule to ensure his son would succeed him. Mubarak is charged with complicity in the killing of more than 800 protesters in the crackdown on a popular uprising that forced him out of office. His two sons, Alaa and Gamal, face corruption charges in the same case.

The prosecutor, Mustafa Suleiman, delivered a scathing critique of Mubarak's rule, branding the 83-year-old a corrupt man whose lust for power will forever tarnish his legacy. Suleiman accused Mubarak of engineering the most fraudulent parliamentary election seen in Egypt since the army seized power in a 1952 coup. Mubarak could face the death penalty if convicted of complicity in the killing of protesters.

The trial has been bogged down in procedural matters, including a demand by lawyers representing the victims that the presiding judge be removed. The trial is expected to continue for several days, with the prosecution presenting its case against Mubarak and 10 other defendants.

details.ground_truth: The final round of voting began in Egypt today, and it looks like the Muslim Brotherhood could walk off with a controlling majority of seats in Parliament's lower house. The Muslim Brotherhood's Freedom and Justice Party, the country's mainstream Islamist party, had already won a high percentage of the seats awarded in the first and second rounds of voting. Two of the nine provinces voting today are Brotherhood strongholds, where some of the party's most well-known candidates are running, the New York Times reports. A plurality, not a majority, was originally predicted for the Freedom and Justice Party. A majority would allow the party to govern alone, but the Brotherhood has repeatedly said it plans to form a coalition government, and has aligned itself with more liberal parties rather than the ultraconservative Salafis, who are in second place with up to 25% of the seats so far. Also today, prosecutors began presenting their case against former Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, Bloomberg notes. His trial resumed last week after a two-month break; state TV today showed Mubarak being carried to and from the courtroom on a gurney. "He deserves an end of humiliation and indignity," said the chief prosecutor, according to the AP.

**Summary of Recent News**

**Incident in Mendon: Car Suspended from Telephone Pole**

A bizarre incident occurred in Mendon on Wednesday evening when a Toyota Corolla, driven by Nabila Altahan, became suspended from a telephone pole's guy wire. According to police, Altahan reacted too quickly to a GPS system's instructions to turn around, causing her to leave the road and the car to become lodged on the wire support.

The incident occurred around 8 p.m. on Route 4 in Mendon, across from the Sugar & Spice Restaurant. Altahan and her passenger were fortunate to have escaped injury in the incident. A witness at the nearby miniature golf course reported seeing the driver jump out of the car as it was suspended from the pole.

The Rutland City Fire Department and State Police responded to the scene, with State Police releasing a statement detailing the events leading up to the incident. The GPS device had given sudden directions to turn around, as the car had passed its intended destination, prompting Altahan's quick reaction.

Fortunately, no one was injured in the incident, and the car was eventually removed from the telephone pole. This unusual incident serves as a reminder of the importance of cautious navigation when using GPS systems.

**No other news was provided.**
details.ground_truth: Police in Vermont say a car ended up almost vertical when the driver swerved quickly in response to her GPS ordering her to "turn around." The car was suspended almost vertically on guide wires attached to a utility pole (see a photo here) in Mendon on Wednesday night, reports the AP. Police say 30-year-old Nabila Altahan of Dorchester, Mass., was headed west on US Route 4 when she passed her intended destination and reacted quickly to the instructions, leaving the road at a significant enough speed to propel the vehicle up the wires. She wasn't injured. (This driver followed her GPS into a lake.)
